questions.text: Acrodynia is seen in poisoning with which of the following metals?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia, or pink disease, is seen in chronic mercury poisoning.

Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating and skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning include:

  • Hydrargyrism - These patients have Danbury tremors, which are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/ Glass blower's shakes
  • Acrodynia (pink disease)
  • Minimata disease - caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury
  • Erethism - these are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity seen in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterised by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia
  • Mercuria lentis - peculiar eye changes due to exposure to mercury vapor.

Related Pearl: Mercury Poisoning

Features

Mercury
Source of exposure

Thermometers (elemental mercury)

Industries (inorganic mercury)

Fish (organic mercury) 
Route of absorption

Elemental - Respiratory tract (negligible through GI unless the mucosa is damaged) 

Inorganic - GI tract

Organic - GI tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

Respiratory tract (elemental mercury)

GI tract (inorganic mercury)

Respiratory + GI tract (organic mercury)
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Renal (elemental mercury)

Renal (inorganic mercury)

CNS (organic mercury)

Mnemonic: MEATS

M -

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis 
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

S-Salivation (excessive salivation)
Diagnosis Blood and/or 24 hour urine mercury level
Treatment BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: Where are blood bags and urine bags discarded, according to biomedical waste management?

choices.text: Both are disposed of in yellow container
Both are disposed of in red container
Urine bag in red container and blood bag in yellow container
Urine bag in yellow container and blood bag in red container

questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management, the urine bags are supposed to be disposed of in the red container and blood bags in the yellow container.

questions.text: An 18-year-old football player presented after collapsing suddenly on the field. The evaluation showed ECG and echocardiographic findings suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in managing HCM with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction(LVOT)?
questions.solution:
Diuretics should be avoided in HCM with LVOT because of their adverse effect on the LV outflow gradient and ventricular volume.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) -

HCM is the leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. 

The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). SAM leads to mitral regurgitation with the jet directed posteriorly. It is characterized by misalignment of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes

Clinical features - While most patients are asymptomatic some of them may develop the following symptoms - dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, presyncope and syncope, and palpitation.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is associated with a mid-systolic murmur with the following features:

  • Loudest along the left sternal border
  • Increases in intensity by maneuvers that result in increasing degrees of outflow tract obstruction:
    • Reduction in preload or afterload: Valsalva, standing, vasodilators
    • Increased contractility: inotropic stimulation  
  • Decreases in intensity when there is
    • Increase in preload: squatting, passive leg raising, volume administration
    • Increase in afterload: squatting, vasopressors
    • Reduced contractility: β-adrenoreceptor blockers

Diagnosis - 

  • ECG - findings include -
    • Prominent abnormal Q waves
    • P wave abnormalities 
    • Left axis deviation.
    • Deeply inverted T waves 
  • Echocardiography -
    •  LV wall thickness ≥15 mm
    • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
    • LVOT(left ventricular outflow tract) obstruction

Treatment -

  • For patients with LVOT obstruction - beta-blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, and disopyramide may be used. Vasodilators and diuretics must be avoided in patients with LVOT obstruction.
  • Patients without LVOT obstruction with LVEF ≥50 percent - Initial monotherapy with either a beta-blocker or a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is started. Diuretics may be used as needed.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: In which of the following conditions treatment with fluoxetine should be avoided?

choices.text: Depression associated with Bipolar I Disorder

questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), and among the given options, it is least suited for the management of hypomania as it may precipitate mania and thus should be avoided.

Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, postpartum depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, generalised anxiety disorders, panic disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder. It is used as an adjunct with Olanzapine (fixed dose) in the management of bipolar depression type I.

The major adverse effects include sexual dysfunction, dry mouth, urinary retention, insomnia, GI disturbances, and weight gain. It should be avoided in patients recovering from depression with suicidal ideation. This is because fluoxetine improves psychomotor withdrawal, permitting the patient to act on preexisting suicidal impulses as they have more energy.

Related Pearl: Adverse effects of specific antidepressants

Drug

Side effect

Amitriptyline

sedation, antimuscarinic, hypotension, arrhythmia, seizures

Fluoxetine

Nausea, anorexia, loss of libido, insomnia

Trazodone

Sedative, priapism, hypotension

Bupropion

Seizures, mild tachycardia, hypertension

Mirtazapine

Sedative, increased appetite, weight gain

questions.text: The ultrasound scan of a pregnant woman given below shows the following finding. Which other ultrasound finding is likely to be seen in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows spina bifida. The other ultrasound sign likely to be seen in this fetus is the lemon sign.

Lemon sign: Axial USG image of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head the appearance of a lemon. It has a strong association with spina bifida and is very useful for detecting this condition.

 

Banana sign: An abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum along with effacement of the cisterna magna produces this appearance. It is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

The given image shows a banana sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A female patient is being evaluated for breast carcinoma. Which of the following subtypes of breast cancer has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast has the worst prognosis.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

The diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer are:

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema and/or peau d’orange, and/or warm breast (with or without an underlying palpable mass)
  • Duration of history no more than six months
  • Erythema occupying at least one-third of the breast
  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma

Cut-off of 6 months for the duration of history differentiates between inflammatory breast carcinoma (≤6 months) and locally advanced breast cancer with secondary erythema (>6 months).

The pathologic hallmark is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis.

Mammography may be normal or show skin thickening. A PET-CT scan should be considered at the time of diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Combined-modality treatment is used, which includes:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Modified radical mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)
  • Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors)

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image.  He also has painful lymphadenopathy and was prescribed Acyclovir for this condition. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding his condition?

choices.text: Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles
Tzanck smear show multinucleated giant cells
Smears are prepared from from the base of vesicles

questions.solution:
The scenario and the image given above are suggestive of herpes infection and they heal without scarring. 

In herpes, clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful lymphadenopathy. The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, which break down into superficial ulcers. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead.

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex Virus infection. The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HSV, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method. Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles, and stained with 1 % aqueous solution of toluidine blue 'O ' for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground glass' chromatin known as Tzanck cells are seen.

Large, multinucleate virus-infected cells with typical eosinophilic Cowdry Type A inclusions are present in a case of Herpes Simplex infection.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)

Darier's Disease "Corps ronds" are isolated keratinocytes with a round shape and an acidophilic cytoplasm. The corps grains are seen as small, hyaline, acidophilic ovoid bodies resembling pomegranate seeds.

questions.text:
Match the following intercellular connections with their structural units:
Section A  Section B 
1. Gap junctions A. Integrins
2. Hemidesmosome B. Claudin
3. Zona occludens C. Desmoglein
4. Desmosome D. Connexons
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair of the following intercellular connections with their structural units is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C. 

Intercellular junctions are connections that are formed between the cells or from the cells to the basal lamina. They are mainly involved in tying the cells to one another, permitting or allowing substances to pass through the cells, anchoring the cells to the basal epithelia, etc. 

The different intercellular connections and their structural units are given below:

Intercellular connections        Structural units          Found in 
i) Cell-to-cell junction    

Tight junctions or zona occludens

 Occludins, claudins, and junctional adhesion molecules Choroid plexus, intestinal mucosa, renal tubular wall

Gap junctions 

 Connexons Intercalated discs in the heart

Zonula adherens where cells are attached to one another with help of actin filaments 

 Cadherins  

Desmosome where intermediate filaments connect cells to one another

 Cadherins like desmoglein  
ii) Cell-to-basement membrane junction    
Hemidesmosomes  Integrins

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count were normal. What is the most suited diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of a pregnant lady with postpartum hemorrhage developing headache, visual changes, and hypotension after a vaginal delivery suggests Sheehan syndrome. 

Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitary gland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage during or after delivery. Patients with SS have varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Also, it can present late with the following features:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, joint pain, and urticarial rash. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Laboratory test reveals eosinophilia. Stool sample microscopy image is given below. Which of the following organism is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing a non-operculated egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Katayama fever caused by Schistosoma mansoni. 

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria.

Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and eosinophilia. Katayama fever can also be caused by  Schistosoma japonicum, but the disease is more severe in S.japanicum due to higher egg production. 

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The eggs deposited in the intestinal wall lead to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose. 

Note:- Praziquantel is the drug of choice for all trematodes except Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica. Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for these.

 

  Schistosoma mansoni Schistosoma japonicum Schistosoma hematobium
Habitat Inferior mesentric vein Superior mesenteric vein Pelvic and vesical plexus
Egg(non operculated egg) Elongated with lateral spine Round with small rudimentary knob Elongated with terminal spine
Definitive host Man Man Man
Intermediate host Freshwater snails Freshwater snails Freshwater snails
Pathogenicity 

Cercarial dermatitis, Katayama fever, and Chronic schistosomiasis - Portal hypertension

Intestinal bilharziasis

Cercarial dermatitis, Katayama fever, and Chronic schistosomiasis - Portal hypertension.

CNS - Seizures(Parietal lobe) in 2-4%

Lung - Corpulmonale in 2-4%

 Cercarial dermatitis, Chronic schistosomiasis - Painless hematuria, dysuria, bladder calculi, and urinary bladder carcinoma(squamous cell carcinoma)

Other options:

Option B- Schistosoma hematobium, the egg has a terminal spine.

Option C- Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

Option D- Schistosoma mekongi is similar to S.japonicum but is slightly smaller and round.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal tract?
  1. They are maximum in the proximal part of the stomach
  2. It is generated by interstitial cells of Cajal
  3. Frequency of these waves in the cecum is 8 per minute
  4. Epinephrine increases the number of spikes and tension
  5. They fluctuate between −65 mV to −45 mV.
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 5 are true regarding basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal system.

Basal electrical rhythm (BER):

The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV. The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:

  • Stomach: 4/min
  • Duodenum: 12/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

  • Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
  • Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, for example, peristalsis in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

Related Pearl: Rate of basal electrical rhythm in various regions

Duodenum

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of drug and the receptor on which it acts:
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is Isoproterenol - β1.

Isoproterenol is a non-selective beta agonist (β1=β2) with no α action. The direct action on cardiac β1 receptors causes an increased risk of tachycardia and arrhythmias. The decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is due to β2 action causing a fall in diastolic blood pressure and

Isoproterenol currently may be used as a cardiac stimulant in patients with bradycardia or heart block, particularly in anticipation of inserting an artificial cardiac pacemaker.

Other options:

Option A: Midodrine is an α1 receptor agonist. It is used for autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension.

Option B: Fenoldopam is a D1 receptor agonist. It is a vasodilator and primarily vasodilates coronary, peripheral, renal, and splanchnic vessels. It also promotes natriuresis and is used in postoperative hypertension and hypertensive crises.

Option C: Dobutamine acts on β1>β2 and α receptors. It is used in cardiac stress testing and acute decompensated heart failure with cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with malaise, fever, a cutaneous ulcer, and preauricular lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with tularemia. Which among the following is a vector that transmits the disease?
questions.solution:
The vector that transmits tularemia is a hard tick.

Hard ticks are ectoparasites of vertebrate animals. They mainly transmit tularemia, tick typhus, and Kyasanur forest disease.

The dorsal surface of a hard tick is covered by scutum which is made up of chitin. This is absent in soft ticks. The head of the hard tick is at the anterior end. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks are:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g. Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis

Tularemia is a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis. It is a gram-negative bacillus and a category A bioterrorism agent. It is a disease of rabbits and rodents. The most common mode of transmission is by direct contact with rodents or tick bites. They manifest as flu-like symptoms with cutaneous ulceration and preauricular lymphadenitis.

Other options:

Option A- Soft tick mainly transmits Q fever and relapsing fever.

Option C- Blackfly mainly transmits onchocerciasis.

Option D- Sandfly mainly transmits kala-azar and oriental sore. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick

Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with acute pericarditis?
questions.solution:
Depression, not elevation, of the PR segment below the TP segment, reflecting atrial involvement, is seen in acute pericarditis.

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. It can be attributed to various causes like infections or inflammatory conditions like RA and SLE, or miscellaneous causes like iatrogenic, neoplasms, drugs, etc.

On auscultation, 85% of patients have a pericardial friction rub. This appears as a rough scratching sound at end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. 

ECG findings of acute pericarditis need to be differentiated from those of myocardial infarction as they are similar.

There are four stages in the development of acute pericarditis ECG changes.

  • Stage 1: Widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment
  • Stage 2: ST segments return to normal after a few days
  • Stage 3: T waves become inverted
  • Stage 4: ECG returns to normal after weeks or months. 

Pericardial effusion is associated with pain and/or ECG changes. it might lead to cardiac tamponade in case of large effusion.

Echocardiography is diagnostic for acute pericarditis. It would reveal a small amount of pericardial fluid. It can also be confirmed by CT or MRI. 

Treatment of acute pericarditis is nonspecific. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are recommended, along with bed rest.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with ataxia telangiectasia. Which of the following inheritance patterns is most likely to be seen in a pedigree chart of his family?
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance seen in ataxia telangiectasia is autosomal recessive which is represented in pedigree chart 1 given above. 

Ataxia telangiectasia is caused due to mutation of the ATM gene. This gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to impaired Ig isotype switching and the formation of antigen receptors. As a result, the patient is immunodeficient and is predisposed to an increased risk of lymphomas. The presenting features will include ataxia, telangiectasia, and neurological deficits.

questions.text: A male patient presents with gait abnormality. He had sustained a lower limb fracture 3 months back. After a detailed evaluation, he was prescribed the splint as shown in the image given below to correct the gait deformity. Which of the following fractures is responsible for the gait deformity for which he is being treated?

choices.text: Fracture of the lower third of tibia

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing an ankle-foot orthosis brace used for the treatment is suggestive of foot drop. It occurs due to common peroneal nerve injury, which is commonly caused by a fracture of the neck of the fibula.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula

It is treated using an ankle-foot orthosis brace - a type of orthotic used to support the foot and ankle in foot drop.

1. Influenza (inactivated) A. Thrombocytopenia

questions.solution:
The option showing 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B shows the correctly matched vaccines with their adverse reactions.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presented with repeated episodes of headache, dizziness, and intense pruritis. Her lab investigations are given below. Bone marrow biopsy showed a hypercellular marrow with prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation. She is also taking treatment for peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following genetic pathologies is strongly associated with this condition?

Lab investigations:

  • Hemoglobin- 17.0 g/dL
  • Hematocrit- 52%
  • Serum erythropoietin- low
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of polycythemia vera which is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

A mutation in JAK2, a key member of the cytokine intracellular signaling pathway, can be found in 90–95% of patients with polycythemia vera.

It is characterized by:

  • Increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis)
  • Low erythropoietin levels and elevated hematocrit
  • Blood viscosity and sludging lead to both thrombosis and bleeding
  • Headache, dizziness, hypertension, dizziness, venous thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome due to hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, and stroke
  • Intense pruritus, especially aquagenic pruritus 
  • Peptic ulceration, hyperuricemia
  • 15% to 20% of patients may develop myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis after few years
  • PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients

Ruxolitinib is the Janus-associated kinase (JAK2) inhibitor used in the treatment of polycythemia vera.

Other options:

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia or CML is the consequence of the balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t[9;22]).

Chronic Eosinophilic Leukemia CEL occurs with a deletion or balanced translocations involving the PDGFRa gene.

BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: Which among the following anticancer drugs is least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, carboplatin is the least likely to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

The important side effects of carboplatin are:

  • Dose-limiting toxicity is myelosuppression, primarily thrombocytopenia
  • Nausea, neurotoxicity, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity (lesser than cisplatin)
  • Hypersensitivity reaction.

Important drugs causing pulmonary fibrosis:

Antimicrobial agents
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Nitrofurantoin
  3. Amphotericin B
Anti-inflammatory drugs

  2. Gold
  3. Infliximab
  4. Penicillamine

  1. ACE-inhibitors
  2. Amiodarone
  3. Flecainide
  4. Procainamide
  5. Hydrochlorothiazide
Chemotherapeutic agents

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman reported that she checks if the front door of her home is locked 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She mentions that this habit is not rational, but if she tries to prevent herself, she feels extremely anxious due to repetitive thoughts that the door is unlocked. Apart from checking her house front door, she also repeatedly checks to see if the gas stove is switched off. Which of the following is least suited for her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Electroconvulsive therapy is the least suited for the management of this condition.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions (doubt that the door is unlocked). Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviors called compulsions (checking if the door is locked) are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

Symptom patterns:

  • Contamination - This is the most common symptom pattern of OCD where objects are perceived to be contaminated followed by either washing or a severe compulsion to avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or may refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.
  • Pathological doubt - This is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession of doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door) which is followed by multiple trips to check, for example, if the stove is turned off.
  • Intrusive thoughts - These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient doesn't agree with which might lead to the patient reporting themselves to the police/confess to a spiritual leader.
  • Symmetry - The patients always need precision or symmetry in the work done and often this can lead to a compulsion of slowness. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

OCD is commonly associated with other common psychiatric comorbidities like depression, social phobia, alcohol use disorders, panic, and personality disorders.

Diagnosis of OCD is by the presence of:

  1. Obsessions, compulsions or both
  2. Time-consuming symptoms
  3. Symptoms not related to substance abuse
  4. Symptoms not better explained by other mental disorders

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: SSRI or clomipramine
  • Behavioral therapy: 
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioral and pharmacotherapy is found to be the most effective.

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: The resin exuding from the leaves and stems of Indian hemp is called:
questions.solution:
The resin exuding from the leaves and stems of Indian hemp is called charas.

Charas is a dark green or brown color resin. It is usually mixed and smoked with tobacco in a pipe, smoke is inhaled deeply into the lungs and retained as long as possible for potent effects. It contains 25-40% of the active principle (tetrahydrocannabinol).

Indian hemp or Cannabis sativa is a CNS stimulant. The principal constituent is cannabinol which has no action but on exposure to heat, it gets converted to a very active isomeric tetrahydrocannabinol. The active component is present in all parts of the plant. 

Different preparations of cannabis include: 

Bhang

  • Prepared from dried leaves and fruit shoot
  • Mildest
  • Contains 15% of active principle
  • Used as we use tea to prepare a decoction

Majoon

  • Sweet prepared with bhang
  • Increases appetite and sexual desire

Ganja

  • Prepared from flower tops of the female plant
  • Contains 15-25% of active principle
  • Mixed and smoked with tobacco in a pipe or hukka

questions.text: The following sign is seen in a patient with spinal cord injury. What is the most likely level of lesion in the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Beevor’s sign indicating a spinal cord lesion at the level T10-T12.

Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A person presents with the deformity shown in the picture and is unable to move the thumb away from the rest of the hand. Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with ape thumb deformity is suggestive of median nerve palsy. Egawa's test is positive in the ulnar nerve injury, not the median nerve injury.

In a positive Egawa test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.

A positive pen test is seen in median nerve palsy. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb. If the patient is unable to touch the pen it signifies a positive pen test.

Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are also used to test median nerve injuries.

The images below show the Benediction hand sign and Ochsner's clasping test.

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a patient is shown below. What is the probable underlying acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH- 7.1

pCO2- 16 mmHg

HCO3- - 6 mEq/L

pO2- 78 mmHg

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis. 

Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula (Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2).

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg

A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

(pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders)

Alternatively:

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the anesthesia department. While intubating a patient, you notice the following type of waveform in capnogram. This capnogram is usually seen in patients with _____.
questions.solution:
The image given is a capnogram seen in patients with esophageal intubation. SpO2 may be normal for 1 or 2 minutes, but then suddenly falls. The waveform that occurs in capnogram is due to the CO2 in the stomach from the swallowed expired air, which gets washed out in a few breaths.

A capnogram is a graphical representation of the partial pressure of CO2 during respiration. It provides information about ventilation, perfusion, and metabolism in an individual.

It is commonly used to confirm endotracheal tube placement. The presence of a normal waveform for at least three breaths is confirmatory. 

The simplest and most widely used form of display for exhaled CO2 is the time capnogram. The time capnogram displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components.

  • Phase 1: Represents the end of inspiration and the beginning of expiration, when the free CO2 gas that occupied the dead space in the airway is exhaled.
  • Phase 2: It represents a rapid rise in PCO2 as alveolar gas appears. 
  • Phase 3: This is a plateau phase where expiration continues but PCO2 doesn't rise any further. The end of this phase is taken as end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2).
  • Phase 4: There is a sharp drop in PCO2 to zero, representing inspiration.

Uses of capnogram:

  1. Surest confirmatory sign of correct intubation.
  2. Diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia.
  3. Detecting obstruction of endotracheal tube.
  4. Indicates cardiac output.
  5. Diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, etc.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis was started on antitubercular therapy. Among the following antitubercular drugs given below, which of the following option selects all the drugs that have a bactericidal action?
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Rifampicin
  3. Pyrazinamide
  4. Ethambutol
  5. Streptomycin
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is the only bacteriostatic agent among the given options. All the options are examples of bactericidal drugs. Therefore, option D (1, 2, 3, 5) is the right answer. 

Bactericidal antituberculosis agents (RIPS)

  • R: Rifampicin (R)
  • I: Isoniazid (H)
  • P: Pyrazinamide (Z)
  • S: Streptomycin (S)

Treatment regimens for pulmonary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis consist of an initial 2-month phase of a 4-drug regimen, followed by a continuation phase of an additional 4 months of isoniazid and rifampin for pulmonary tuberculosis.

Isoniazid is used for the treatment of tuberculosis (as part of combination therapy) or for latent tuberculosis infection (as monotherapy or part of combination therapy). The antimicrobial activity of INH is selective for mycobacteria, likely due to its ability to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis, which interferes with cell wall synthesis, thereby producing a bactericidal effect 

Rifampicin is thought to inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which appears to occur as a result of drug binding in the polymerase subunit deep within the DNA/RNA channel, facilitating direct blocking of the elongating RNA. Along with Isoniazid, Rifampicin is also given in both the initial phase and continuation phase of the treatment of TB.

Pyrazinamide is most commonly used for the treatment of active tuberculosis (TB) during the initial phase of therapy only(generally the first two months of treatment), in combination with other agents. The spectrum of pyrazinamide is relatively narrow; it demonstrates clinically significant antibacterial activity only against Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium africanum.

Streptomycin is an injectable drug, also a bactericidal drug used sometimes in the initial phase of treatment of pulmonary TB.

Ethambutol is the only drug in the initial phase which is an example of a bacteriostatic drug. There is evidence that the drug exerts its bacteriostatic activity by virtue of inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme that polymerizes arabinose into arabinan and then arabinogalactan, a mycobacterial cell wall constituent.

Related Pearl: General properties of the first line drugs in TB

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.

  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the hospital in a semi-conscious state. He is sweating profusely, has muscle weakness, breathlessness with an audible wheeze, and constricted pupils. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with carbaryl poisoning. Which of the following should not be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Pralidoxime should not be used for the treatment of carbaryl poisoning.

Oximes like pralidoxime are used to restore neuromuscular transmission in organophosphate anti­ChE poisoning. It attaches to the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme, which remains unoccupied in the presence of organophosphates. It binds and forms oxime-phosphonate which diffuses away, leaving the reactivated cholinesterase.

Pralidoxime is not an effective anti­dote to carbamates like carbaryl. This is because the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme is not free for attachment to pralidoxime. Hence, it does not reactivate the carbamylated enzyme. Carbamates spontaneously disassociate from AChE and recover in 24-48 hours.

Pralidoxime may potentiate the toxicity of carbaryl. Therefore, pralidoxime should be avoided in known single-agent carbaryl poisonings. However, pralidoxime is considered for use in mixed poisonings with an organophosphorus compound and a carbamate.   

Other options:

Option B: Atropine is the mainstay in the management of carbamate poisoning. It is the antidote of choice, given for muscarinic symptoms. Atropine is usually sufficient till the carbamylated acetylcholinesterase complex dissociates spontaneously and recovers function. This occurs usually within 24 hours.

Option C: Diazepam may be used for the management of seizures in carbaryl poisoning.

Option D: Activated charcoal can be used to perform gastric lavage in oral carbamate poisoning.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain was prescribed a drug that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog. Mechanism of action is a combination of effects as mentioned below-

  • Weak agonist action on the mu-opioid receptor
  • Inhibition of serotonin reuptake transporter (moderate action) and norepinephrine reuptake transporter (weak action). 

It is used to induce analgesia for moderate pain and can be used as an adjunct to opioid therapy in chronic pain conditions. 

Other options: They do not affect serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

Option A: Hydromorphone is a phenanthrene drug with strong mu-opioid agonist action with a variable affinity for delta and kappa receptors. It is similar to morphine.  

Option C: Buprenorphine is also a phenanthrene derivative that has mixed opioid agonist-antagonist activity. It is a partial mu-agonist and has antagonist activity at delta and kappa receptors. While it can serve as an analgesic, it antagonizes the action of strong mu-agonists such as morphine. It is used to treat moderate pain and reduced cravings in patients recovering from alcoholism.

Option D: Hydrocodone is a phenanthrene drug with mild-moderate mu-opioid agonist action. It is less efficacious than morphine.

questions.text: A deficiency of the membrane attack complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections. The membrane attack complex is composed of which of the following complement components?
questions.solution:
The complement components that form the membrane attack complex are C5b6789. 

The complement system is a collection of soluble proteins and their membrane receptors that help in host defense against microbes and pathologic inﬂammatory reactions. It consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 to C9.

An important step in complement activation involves the proteolysis of the third component, C3, which is also the most abundant complement, by one of the following three pathways:

  1. The classical pathway, triggered by fixation of C1 to either an IgM or IgG antibody
  2. The alternative pathway, triggered by microbial surface molecules like endotoxins
  3. The lectin pathway, in which C1 is activated by binding of plasma lectin to carbohydrates on microbes

During inflammation, C5a, C3a, and C4a, which are all cleavage products of their corresponding complement components, stimulate mast cells to release histamine. They have effects similar to those of mast cell mediators involved in anaphylactic reactions and therefore, are called anaphylatoxins. Thereby increasing vascular permeability and vasodilatation.

C5a is also chemotactic for neutrophils, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Additionally, it activates the lipooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, resulting in the further release of inflammatory mediators.

Complement factor C5b binds to the late components C6-C9, resulting in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Neisseria has thin cell walls, hence it is susceptible to lysis due to MAC. Hence, deficiency of this complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was admitted to your hospital with multiple pigmented papular lesions on his face, neck, forearm, and corneal injection following the exposure to the sun as shown below.  On further investigations, cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinoma were found. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple lesions on the sun-exposed area and multiple cutaneous malignancies are suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin.

XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

questions.text:
A senior resident uses the following system of classification while evaluating a woman, who was diagnosed with maxillary carcinoma. Identify the correct statements regarding this system of classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  1. The lines marked 'A' and 'B' in the image are called Sebileau lines.
  2. The name of this classification is Ohngren classification.
  3. The respiratory part of the nose is included under mesostructure.
  4. The vertical lines in this classification extend down the medial walls of orbit to separate sphenoidal sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.
  5. The suprastructure marked in the image contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lederman’s classification and the correct statements regarding this classification include 1, 3, 5.

Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma and the two horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the above image are called Sebileau lines, one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through the floors of the antrum.

 Sebileau lines divide the area into:

  • Suprastructure: It contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
  • Mesostructure: It has a maxillary sinus and the respiratory part of the nose.
  • Infrastructure: It contains the alveolar process.

This classification further uses vertical lines, extending down the medial walls of orbit to separate ethmoidal sinuses (not sphenoidal sinuses) and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.


Note:

Ohngren's classification is also used to classify maxillary carcinoma. It includes Ohngren’s line, which is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible.

Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of the procedure shown in the image over its midline counterpart?

choices.text: Lesser chance of anal sphincter involvement

questions.solution:
The above image shows mediolateral episiotomy. The primary advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy is that there is a lesser chance of anal sphincter involvement due to extension. 

An episiotomy is an intended incision of the perineum with the goal of enlargement of the vaginal opening for birth. Prior to episiotomy, analgesia is provided by existing labor regional analgesia, bilateral pudendal nerve block, or local infiltration with 1% lignocaine. Typically, an episiotomy is completed when the head is visible during a contraction to a diameter of 4 to 5 cm.

Midline episiotomy begins at the fourchette, incises the perineal body in the midline, and ends well before the external anal sphincter. Mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle of 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for the stretch distortion of the perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and resolution of the distortion, it ultimately yields an incision 45 degrees from the midline for suturing.

Midline episiotomy Mediolateral episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is less Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative pain is less

Postoperative pain is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the anal sphincter

Extension, even if it occurs, will not involve the anal sphincter

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be associated with the blood picture shown in the peripheral smear given below?

choices.text: Recent attack of gastroenteritis by E. coli

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows schistocytes and helmet cells suggesting hemolytic anemia. Defective DNA cross-link repair is unlikely to cause hemolytic anemia. 

Defective DNA cross-link repair causes a rare, autosomal recessive disorder called Fanconi anemia. It is characterized by aplastic anemia, developmental anomalies, leukemia, and increased hypersensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents. Aplastic anemia features a hypocellular bone marrow resulting in primary hematopoietic failure and pancytopenia.

Schistocytes and helmet cells are commonly seen in microangiopathic and macroangiopathic hemolytic conditions caused due to trauma to red cells. Artificial mechanical heart valves (option A) are the most commonly implicated cause. The shear forces produced by turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients across damaged valves account for hemolysis.

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen in:

  1. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  2. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  3. Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  4. Malignant hypertension
  5. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  6. Metastatic cancer

The common pathology behind these conditions includes the presence of a microvascular lesion that leads to luminal narrowing and subsequent shear stress that mechanically injures the passing red cells. Traumatic damage of red cells leads to intravascular hemolysis and the appearance of fragmented red cells (schistocytes). Burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells may also be seen in these conditions.

Other options:

Option B: Recent attack of infectious gastroenteritis may be a possible cause since infection with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli can result in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Option C: TTP is caused due to ADAMTS13 deficiency. This plasma enzyme is also called vWF metalloprotease.

questions.text: The most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery is:
questions.solution:
After-cataract is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery.

After cataract, otherwise known as posterior capsular opacification/ secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls - present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring - presents as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type - present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

The illustration given below shows different types of after-cataract.

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It becomes indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Other options: 

Option A: Retinal detachment is an uncommon late complication of cataract surgery. It may occur in people with pre-operative risk factors such as retinal breaks, high myopia, or due to vitreous loss during surgery. Retinal detachment is treated by pars plana vitrectomy.

Option B: Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation. Patients complain of pain and visual loss. Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitritis. Intravitreal antibiotics are the key to management. Other treatment modalities include oral antibiotics and steroids, and pars plana vitrectomy.

Option C: Irvine–Gass syndrome is postoperative cystoid macular edema. It is an uncommon late complication of cataract surgery. It is clinically insignificant; resolves on its own.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was brought to the EEG room. He was asked to stay awake and relax with his eyes closed. Which of the following waves will be detected in his EEG?
questions.solution:
Alpha rhythm waves will be detected in the EEG in an awake and relaxed patient with his eyes closed.

Sleep is comprised of two distinct physiological states: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and REM sleep. Stages I to IV make up the NREM sleep with marked lower physiological functions than during wakefulness. During REM sleep, except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is increased during this time. 

Wakefulness: Low-voltage, mixed frequency activity. When eyes are closed, alpha activity is noted. Eye movements and eye blinks are present, with high muscle tonic activity and voluntary movements.

NREM sleep is composed of stages 1 through 4. About 90 minutes after sleep onset, NREM yields to the first REM episode of the night. Non-REM sleep is divided into four stages:

Stage 1: The transition from wakefulness to sleep. EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed-frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) is seen during this stage with vertex sharp waves. There are slow eye movements.

Stage 2: Presence of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz) and K complexes, which are negative sharp waves followed by a positive slow wave. There are no eye movements; muscle tone is reduced.

Stage 3: Presence of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz). There is a further reduction in muscle tone and arousal and no eye movements.

Stage 4: A characteristic pattern of rhythmic slow waves, sometimes referred to as slow-wave sleep. While the occurrence of theta and delta rhythms is normal during sleep. No eye movements and low muscle tone.

REM sleep is characterized by an EEG pattern consisting of low-voltage, random, fast activity with sawtooth waves, as well as theta activity and slow alpha waves.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: The image shows the dorsum of the hand. What is the action of the marked structure on the fingers?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the dorsal interossei of the hand. Their action is abduction of the fingers.

Dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles originating from the adjacent metacarpal bone. They attach to the middle three fingers on both sides and do not attach to the thumb and little finger. 

Muscle Dorsal Interossei
Origin Contiguous sides of shafts of metacarpal bones
Insertion Proximal phalanges of index, middle, and ring fingers and dorsal extensor expansion
Nerve supply Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Nerve roots C8; T1
Action  

Dorsal interossei abduct fingers from the center of the third finger, flex metacarpophalangeal joints and extend interphalangeal joints

 

 

Dorsal digital expansion or Extensor expansion is a small triangular aponeurosis covering the dorsum of the proximal phalanx formed by the expansion of the tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus. The muscles joining the expansion are extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis.
