questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 8 weeks of gestation presents to the OPD with greenish frothy vaginal discharge. The OPD is located in a rural setting and the laboratory facilities are unavailable. Examination reveals the finding as shown below. Which of the following is the appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Treat the patient and her husband with acyclovir
Treat the patient with oral tinidazole
Treat the patient only with acyclovir
Treat the patient with trichofuran suppositories and betadine gel

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in which the patient has greenish, frothy vaginal discharge in her first trimester of pregnancy and the image showing the strawberry cervix are suggestive of vaginal trichomoniasis. The appropriate management approach would be to treat the patient with trichofuran suppositories and betadine gel as the patient is in the first trimester.

Metronidazole may be used in all pregnancy stages although some studies suggest avoiding its use during 1st trimester. Some alternatives that can be used in the treatment of this infection include trichofuran suppositories and betadine gel. 

Trichomonas vaginalis is one of the most common causes of vaginal discharge. It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4–21 days. The clinical features include vaginal discharge which is profuse, thin, slightly green in colour, and frothy. 

It may be associated with vaginal irritation, pruritus, dysuria, and increased frequency. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots. Motile trichomonads are seen on wet mount examination. Males can be asymptomatic or develop non-specific urethritis. 

Administration of metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose or 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days is the standard treatment. It should be taken at night, after meals to avoid vomiting. If this too causes vomiting, or in resistant cases consider the use of alternative drugs.

The alternative regimen includes tinidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days or secnidazole in a single dose of 1000 mg daily for 2 days. The use of tinidazole is not recommended during pregnancy. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A patient with HIV had a CD4+ count of 170/ μL. Prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii is started. When can the prophylaxis be stopped?
questions.solution:
Prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii with trimethoprim-sulphamethoxazole can be stopped when CD4+ T-cell count >200/μL for ≥3 months.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance of symptomatic pneumocystis pneumonia consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests which are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment and prevention of PCP are with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Prophylaxis is indicated for other opportunistic infections like 

  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, if CD4 counts fall below 50 cells/µL
  • Coccidioides, if CD count is <250/µL
  • Cryptococcus, when the CD count is <100/µL.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells. The culture on MacConkey agar showed the appearance of non-lactose fermenting colonies. Phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) Reaction is positive. What is the most likely organism implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicating, non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar, and a positive Phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) Reaction in a patient with lower urinary tract symptoms is suggestive of Proteus infection.

Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus. All members of the tribe Protea have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. This is called the PPA reaction.

Proteus can cause urinary tract infections. Struvite stones (triple phosphate stones) are usually seen in a setting of infection with urease-producing bacteria like Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

Image showing a positive PPA reaction:

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.


Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as,

Lactose fermenters Escherichia, Klebsiella, Enterobacter 
Late lactose fermenters Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia
Non-lactose fermenters Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus


Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S. sonnei, which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum

Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens

questions.text: Which of the following is the World Mental Health Day theme for the year 2022?

choices.text: Mental Health for all. Greater Investment – Greater Access.
Making mental health for all a global priority
Mental health in an unequal world
Young people and mental health in the changing world

questions.solution:
The mental health day theme for 2022 is 'Making Mental Health and Well-Being for All a Global Priority'.

World mental health day is observed on 10th October. This theme was adopted for the year 2022 as the COVID-19 pandemic has created a global crisis for mental health in the last two years.

Mental health day themes for the past few years are as follows:

2021: Mental health in an unequal world.

2020: Mental Health for all. Greater Investment – Greater Access. Everyone, everywhere.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with major depressive disorder on fluoxetine complains of sexual dysfunction. She is a smoker and her medical history includes bulimia nervosa and diabetes mellitus. Her physician plans to stop fluoxetine and switch to bupropion, due to its low incidence of sexual side effects. However, which of the following could be a reason to avoid bupropion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bupropion is associated with an increased risk of seizures in patients with bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa. For this reason, bupropion is contraindicated in these patients.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine are the first-line management of the major depressive disorder. The most common adverse effect of SSRIs is sexual dysfunction. Among the second-line drugs, bupropion has a low incidence of sexual side effects. But, bupropion increases the risk of seizures in patients with bulimia nervosa.

Buproprion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine. It is also used for the treatment of attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder, obesity, smoking dependence, and peripheral neuropathy.

Buproprion is the most anxiogenic antidepressant. Adverse effects of bupropion include stimulant side effects like tachycardia, insomnia, headache, and seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients. It decreases the risk of sexual dysfunction and weight gain compared to other antidepressants.

Atypical anti-depressants such as mirtazapine and bupropion do not cause sexual dysfunction.

Other options:

Option A: A history of smoking would further prompt the use of bupropion in this patient because it aids in smoking cessation.

Options C and D: Diabetes mellitus and age are not contraindications for the use of bupropion.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with severe abdominal cramps and diarrhea. 3 days ago she was diagnosed with cellulitis and was started on antibiotics. She is a known case of depression for which she takes paroxetine. On examination, she is agitated and delirious. Her BP was 180/100 mmHg and her pulse rate was 120/min. Bilateral hyperreflexia and ankle clonus were also noted. Which of the following antibiotics was the patient most likely given to treat the cellulitis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. Linezolid is likely to have caused her symptoms. 

Linezolid is used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, particularly vancomycin-resistant enterococcus and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Linezolid has MAOI (monoamine oxidase inhibitors) activity and therefore can precipitate serotonin syndrome with concomitant use of SSRI (paroxetine) or with other serotonergic medications.

Serotonin syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium.
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus.

Serotonin syndrome rarely occurs with a single serotonergic drug used at therapeutic doses. More commonly, it occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options:

Vancomycin, clindamycin, and doxycycline do not have MAOI effects. They do not cause serotonin syndrome when combined with a serotonergic antidepressant.

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

 Syndrome
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

questions.text: A 68-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. The radiological investigations reveal a tumor arising from a major bronchus. Histopathology shows small cells with a salt and pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 68-year-old chronic smoker presenting with cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain with radiological findings of a tumor arising from a major bronchus and histopathology showing small cells with a salt and pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls (Azzopardi effect) is most likely small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Small cell carcinoma of the lung belongs to the neuroendocrine tumors and originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells, Kulchitsky cells that lines the bronchial epithelium. It is a highly malignant tumor with a high association with cigarette smoking. They mainly arise from the major bronchi.

Histopathology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells which are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and a prominent nuclear molding. These cells have scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to coating by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Neuroendocrine markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

  • Chromogranin
  • Synaptophysin
  • CD56

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion. Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. 

Other options:

Option A- Adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor with differentiation in glands or mucin production by the tumor cells. These tumors are commonly found in women and in non-smokers. These tumors are more peripherally located and are smaller. On histopathology, the tumor shows a lepidic pattern of spread with tumor cells crawling along the normal-appearing alveolar septa. The tumor cells are positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Option B- Squamous cell carcinoma is found to be more common in men and has a strong association with smoking. They have precursor lesions like squamous dysplasia, squamous metaplasia, or in situ carcinomas. On histopathology, it is characterized by keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization occurs in the form of squamous pearls. It is positive for p40 and p63 markers. Hypercalcemia is the common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this type.

Option C- Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial carcinoma. On histopathology, the cells are large, with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli with a moderate amount of cytoplasm. 

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

questions.text: A study compares the body weights of a group of individuals before and after putting them on a special diet. Which of the following tests is used in this case?
questions.solution:
This study involves a quantitative variable, i.e, body weight, and compares the before and after results of the same group. Hence, paired T-test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following primitive reflexes would persist throughout life?
questions.solution:
The parachute reflex persists throughout life.

The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex. It is elicited by holding the infant's trunk and then suddenly lowering them as if they were falling. This will cause the infant's arms to extend in order to break the fall. Thus, it is a prerequisite for walking. The onset of this reflex is at 7-8 months of age, it fully develops by 10-11 months and persists for life. 

Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific times during a child's development. Any persistence or absence of these reflexes is significant for central nervous system dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

 
Reflex

2-3 months postnatal
Rooting

5-6 months postnatal

35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used in a patient with severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Device 2 shown in the above image represents a cochlear implant, which can be used in a patient with bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Cochlear implant:

  • An electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid.
  • Principle- surgery to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach
  • The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. (Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.)

The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are part of the internal component of the cochlear implant. Microphone, speech processor, and transmitter are part of the external component of the cochlear implant, which remains outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea and convert the sound signal to electrical impulses, which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.


Other options: 

Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia. Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA, that combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear – a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Bone-anchored Hearing Aids are used:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal are associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids.
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia.
  • In Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • In Single-sided deafness

Device 3 is a picture of a stapedectomy piston, used in patients with otosclerosis.

Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes is structurally intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of loose stools. The transmission electron micrograph of the causative agent is given in the image below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electron micrograph image is suggestive of rotavirus.

Rotavirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded (ds) RNA virus. Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. It has 11 segments of double-stranded RNA. They exhibit genetic reassortment due to the presence of this segmented RNA.

Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 months of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens.

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a potential risk of intussusception, especially when the first dose of these vaccines is given to infants aged >12 weeks. Because of this risk, the rotavirus vaccine is not a part of catch-up immunization programs.

Other options:

Option A: Adenovirus contains double-stranded DNA. They have an icosahedral symmetry with structures known as fibers extruding from the vertices. They have a space vehicle-shaped appearance.

Option B: Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

Option C: Rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae are bullet-shaped viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: A genetic scientist was studying the mechanisms occurring after transcriptional events in eukaryotic cells mRNA. One such process is the polyadenylation of mRNA, which protects against the degradation of mRNA by which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Polyadenylation of mRNA protects against degradation by 3’ exonucleases.

5’ capping protects the mRNA against attacks by 5’ exonucleases. Sequences in the 5’ and 3’ ends as well as in the coding region of the mRNA are thought to either protect against or facilitate endonuclease action.

After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly-A tail, and splicing.

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre-mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backward to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. These tails help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation.
  • Splicing: The maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns and joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. The process of removing introns and joining exons is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

Image depicting the steps of transcription:

questions.text: A 13-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty after sustaining an electric injury at home. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Lichtenberg's figures or filigree burns are not seen in this type of electrical injury. They are a superficial, thin, tortuous, fern-like pattern of erythema on the skin and are pathognomonic of lightning burns.

The image given below shows Lichtenberg's figures.

Lesions seen in electrical burns or electrocution:

Joule burns are specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. These are found at the point of the entry of the current. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter. 

The image given below shows a Joule burn.

Spark lesions are seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and the conductor. They occur due to outer skin keratin melting over a small area which on cooling fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface. The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings. 

The crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns causing multiple spark lesions.

The image given below shows high voltage burns due to electrocution causing multiple spark lesions i.e. crocodile skin effect.

The image below shows the various electrical marks:

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man undergoes a renal transplant from an HLA-matched sibling. The transplant is successful and he is kept on immunosuppression with cyclosporine. 2 months later as the immunosuppression is tapered, he develops fever and flank pain on the transplanted side. There is an associated decrease in urine volume. A tissue biopsy confirms the diagnosis of acute transplant rejection. Which of the following statements is/are true?

1. It develops days, weeks or much later once immunosuppression is tapered.
2. The immunohistochemical staining of the biopsy specimen may show both CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration.
3. It manifests as interstitial fibrosis and arteriosclerosis.
4. All arterioles and arteries show fibrinoid necrosis.
5. It is mediated by T cells and antibodies that are activated by alloantigens in the graft.
questions.solution:
The true statements about acute transplant rejection are 1,2 and 5.

Acute transplant rejection is due to the activation of T cells and antibodies by the alloantigens in the graft. Hence, it takes time to develop and may be seen within a few days, weeks or much later when immunosuppression is tapered. This is the principal cause of early graft failure.

In acute rejection, both CD8+ and CD4+ T cells act by directly destroying the graft cells and by inducing inflammation in the graft respectively. The immunochemical staining of the biopsy specimen may show both CD4 (helper) and CD8 (cytotoxic) lymphocyte infiltration.

T-cell mediated rejection may present as 2 patterns: tubulointerstitial and vascular.

Acute antibody-mediated rejection manifests primarily by damage to the glomeruli and small blood vessels. There is inflammation and deposition of complement products in the glomeruli and the peritubular capillaries. The small vessels may be focally thrombosed.

False statements:

All arterioles and arteries show fibrinoid necrosis in hyperacute transplant rejection. It is due to pre-formed antibodies. It can be avoided by pre-transplant HLA typing and cross-matching. 

Chronic transplant rejection manifests as interstitial fibrosis and arteriosclerosis. It has predominant vascular changes. It occurs over months to years after transplantation. It is believed to be due to the action of T cells against graft alloantigens. This leads to fibroblast and vascular smooth muscle proliferation in the graft. Chronic rejection is usually refractory to treatment.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A 29-year-old married woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Her urinary pregnancy test is positive but her ultrasound shows an empty uterus and no gestational sac was found in the adnexa. An ectopic pregnancy is suspected. All of the following  are features in favor of a clinical diagnosis of cervical pregnancy, except _______.

choices.text: Enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
A fully opened internal cervical os
Products of conceptus attached within endocervix

questions.solution:
All the given options are in favor of a clinical diagnosis of cervical pregnancy except fully opened internal cervical os.

A closed internal cervical os is one of the clinical diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy, not an open one.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where implantation occurs in the cervical canal at or below the internal os. Thinning and distension of the cervical canal occur due to erosion of the walls by the trophoblasts. The morbidity and mortality are high due to profuse bleeding.

Rubin's diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy:

  • Uterine bleeding without cramping pain following a period of amenorrhea
  • A soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix
  • A closed internal cervical os
  • A partially opened external cervical os

Ultrasound examination reveals the pregnancy in the cervical canal and an empty uterine cavity.

Management medical and surgical therapy. Methotrexate therapy or feticidal KCl injection may be considered in a few selected cases. Surgery includes a hysterectomy, as it is often required to stop bleeding. Uterine artery embolization with gel foam can also be used to control hemorrhage.

questions.text:
With regards to prostate carcinoma, which of the following Gleason's grade group is incorrectly matched with Gleason's score?
Options Gleason's grade group Gleason's score
A Group 1 6
B Group 2 7
C Group 3 8
D Group 5 10
questions.solution:
The incorrectly matched option is option C.

A prostate cancer patient with Gleason's grade groups 2 and 3 both have a score of 7.

Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score:

1) Gleason Pattern:

    • Pattern 3- Well formed glands
    • Pattern 4- Poorly formed/ Fused/ Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands
    • Pattern 5- Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords, and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis
    • Patterns 1 and 2 are no longer defined

2) Gleason Score:

The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned.

3) Grade group:

    • Grade group 1: score ≤6
    • Grade group 2: 3+4=7
    • Grade group 3: 4+3=7
    • Grade group 4: score 8
    • Grade group 5: scores 9–10.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about psoriasis are correct?
  1. Koebner phenomenon is seen.
  2. It is not exacerbated by lithium.
  3. Guttate psoriasis is the most common type.
  4. Auspitz sign is seen.
  5. Psoriatic arthritis is a complication.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, statements 1, 4, and 5 are correct about psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region.

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause the proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring termed Koebner's phenomenon (statement 1). It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. 

Psoriasis can be exacerbated by medications (statement 2) like lithium, synthetic antimalarials, interferon-alpha, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha. 

The clinical variants of psoriasis include plaque, guttate, pustular, erythrodermic, unstable, and atypical forms. It can also be classified based on the site involved. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis (statement 3). Plaque psoriasis accounts for 80-90% of all cases. 

Scalp psoriasis does not frequently cause alopecia. The scalp is one of the more common areas to be affected by psoriasis and is often affected first. The involvement of the scalp is very variable with widespread plaques or multiple discrete patches. Hair growth is generally unaffected but it can occur.

Removing the psoriatic scales leads to pinpoint bleeding, termed the Auspitz sign (statement 4). 

Psoriasis is treated with PUVA, which is psoralen with ultraviolet light - A (UVA) and NBUVB (narrow band UVB). Systemic drugs can be used in severe cases like methotrexate, retinoids, cyclosporine, and fumarate. 

Complications of psoriasis include secondary infection, poor cosmetic appearance, risk of lymphoma, and psoriatic arthritis (statement 5).

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrectly matched pair among the given antiglaucoma drugs and their mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
The incorrectly matched pair is option C.

Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin analog that acts by increasing aqueous drainage, without affecting the aqueous humor production. 

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs are used as a first line in glaucoma. Latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone are used as anti-glaucoma drugs.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by altering the ciliary muscle tension and improving the outflow of the aqueous humor.

Adverse effects:

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema especially in aphakic patients. 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the boundaries of the foramen marked as 'A' in the given image?
questions.solution:
The epiploic foramen is marked as 'A' in the given image. It is related posteriorly to the inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of the T12 vertebra.

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated immediately posterior to the free margin of the lesser omentum. It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac. It measures about 3 cm in height in adults.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Anterior – Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct.
  • Posterior – T12 vertebra, inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.
  • Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text:
A patient with a history of decreased urine output reports to the hospital. Inulin clearance test revealed decreased clearance. Which of the following factors can lead to this finding?
  1. Chronic uncontrolled hypertension
  2. Strong activation of renal sympathetic nerves
  3. PGE-2 release
  4. Endothelin infusion
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, Options 1, 2, and 4 can lead to decreased clearance of inulin.

Inulin clearance is used to measure the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Decreased inulin clearance is associated with decreased GFR. 

GFR is the amount of plasma ultrafiltrate formed each minute and can be measured by estimating the plasma level of a substance and the amount of that substance that is excreted. The substance used to measure GFR must be freely filtered through the glomeruli and must be neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the tubules. Eg. Inulin.

GFR is determined by the equation GFR = Kf × net filtration pressure, where Kf is the filtration coefficient.

In chronic uncontrolled hypertension, there is increased thickness of the glomerular capillary basement membrane and loss of capillary function due to severe damage. Hence, there is a gradual reduction in Kf, which leads to a decrease in GFR.

The afferent and efferent arterioles of the kidney are richly innervated by sympathetic nerve fibers. Strong activation of the renal sympathetic nerves can constrict the renal arterioles and decrease renal blood flow, which brings about a decrease in GFR. However, moderate or mild sympathetic stimulation has little influence on renal blood flow and GFR.

Endothelin is a potent vasoconstrictor and pro-fibrotic growth factor. In the renal cortex, ET binds to the ETA receptor resulting in afferent vasoconstriction and decreasing renal blood flow and GFR.

Prostaglandins PGE2 along with PGI2 and bradykinin, serve as hormones and autacoids that cause vasodilation, thereby resulting in increased renal blood flow and increased GFR.

questions.text:
A child presents with generalized swelling of the body. Urinary examination findings are given below. What will be the findings on light microscopy examination of the renal biopsy?

Urine examination: 3+ protein; presence of hyaline & fatty casts; no RBCs
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with generalized swelling of the body, urinary examination revealing 3+ protein, presence of hyaline & fatty casts, and no RBCs, is strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease (MCD). Light microscopy of the renal tissue shows a normal appearance in this condition.

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years).

Biopsy findings in this condition are as follows:

  • Light microscopy - glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change').
  • Immunofluorescence studies - no Ig or complement deposits.
  • Electron microscopy - diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy).

Other options:

Option A: Subepithelial humps are seen in post-infectious glomerulonephritis which presents with fever, oliguria, and hematuria 1-2 weeks after recovery from sore throat. This finding is appreciated on electron microscopy.

Option C: Effacement of podocytes is seen in minimal change disease. However, this finding cannot be appreciated on light microscopy. It is seen on electron microscopy.

Option D: There are no immune deposits in minimal change disease. Immunofluorescence study, and not light microscopy, is used to detect immune deposits.

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A  26-year-old male patient presents with painful ulcers on his penis with the classical "kissing ulcer" appearance. He also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.  Which of the following will be found on microscopy of the smear from these lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender genital ulcers with the "kissing ulcer" appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy most likely has a diagnosis of chancroid. The classical "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance will be found on microscopy of the smear from these lesions, as shown below:

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings, "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance.

Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g oral) or ceftriaxone (250mg intramuscular).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform and treat their sexual partners from the last 3 months.

Other options:

(B) Spirochetes are seen on dark field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis can be confirmed by specific treponemal tests such as fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS), Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test (TPHA), and the enzyme immunoassay (EIA). Treatment is with parental penicillin G, irrespective of the stage of the disease. Dose and duration depend on the clinical stage and presentation. In the case of penicillin hypersensitivity, regimens based on doxycycline, erythromycin, tetracycline, and chloramphenicol are used for treatment.

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes are shown below:


(C) Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Management is with a course of azithromycin.

The slide below shows Donovan bodies with the safety-pin appearance:


(D) Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base with painful inguinal lymph nodes. The diagnosis can be made with an initial Tzanck smear by deroofing the vesicles and taking a swab. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing can be used to confirm this diagnosis. The first-line drug used to treat herpes genitalis is oral aciclovir.

Tzanck smear with the above-mentioned findings can be seen below:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text:
You are a gynecologist with a special interest in hormone replacement therapy (HRT). Among the following patients, to whom would you avoid prescribing HRT?
  1. A 35-year-old woman who has undergone total abdominal hysterectomy+bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
  2. A 65-year-old woman having hot flushes with undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  3. A 57-year-old woman having hot flushes and risk factors for developing osteoporosis
  4. A 62-year-old woman with atrophic vaginitis and a history of myocardial infarction 10 months ago
  5. A 52-year-old woman with irritability and hot flushes, with a history of deep vein thrombosis in her previous pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is contraindicated in cases 2, 4, and 5.

HRT involves the cyclical administration of estrogen and progesterone, where estrogen is administered for 25 days followed by a progestin for 10-12 days. Re-evaluation for further need for HRT is done every 6-12 months. The progestin is added to lower the risk of developing endometrial cancer.

Contraindications for HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal bleeding from the genital tract
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer, or estrogen-dependent neoplasias
  • Active or previous history venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic diseases such as stroke or myocardial infarction
  • Liver or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of HRT
  • Known or suspected pregnancy

Indications for HRT:

  • Therapeutic:
    • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency- vasomotor symptoms, vaginal atrophy
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic: High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as
    • Cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
    • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nucleus lies under the elevation of the marked area?
questions.solution:
The elevation marked in the image, in the lowermost area of the rhomboid fossa away from the striae medullaris is known as the vagal trigone. The vagal nucleus is present beneath the vagal trigone.

The given image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped or rhomboid-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves V to XII. The fourth ventricle is continuous with the cerebral aqueduct cranially and the central canal of the spinal cord caudally.

The fourth ventricular floor is divided into superior and inferior halves by the striae medullaris. The superior triangular half is limited laterally by the superior cerebellar peduncles. The inferior triangular half is limited caudally by the gracile and cuneate tubercles that form the dorsal column. The floor is divided vertically into two halves by a longitudinal sulcus called the median sulcus. Each vertical half is further divided by the sulcus limitans to form the medial eminence and the lateral vestibular area.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (rhomboid fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullaris divide the floor into superior and inferior halves.

Medial to lateral in upper triangular part:

  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence contain the facial colliculus coiled around the abducens nucleus.
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area contains the vestibular nucleus

Sulcus limitans forms:

  • The bluish-colored area at the uppermost end of sulcus limitans denotes the underlying locus coeruleus
  • Superior fovea: A small depression between the facial colliculus and the vestibular area
  • Inferior fovea: lateral limit of sulcus limitans

Lower triangular part:

  • Hypoglossal trigone: represents the medial eminence in the lower triangle. It consists of the hypoglossal nucleus.
  • Vagal trigone: Is present caudal to the hypoglossal triangle consisting of the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve
  • Funiculus separans: A narrow translucent ridge that is present caudal to the vagal trigone. It is separated from the gracile tubercle by the small area postrema separating it from the vagal trigone.

The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the superior and inferior medullary veli. 

Given below are a schematic and clinical specimen depicting the structures present in the floor of the fourth ventricle:

questions.text: During the cardiovascular examination of a pregnant woman, which among the following findings is not considered physiological change?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, exaggerated splitting of S2 is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy.

Physiological changes in the cardiovascular system in pregnancy:

  • Exaggerated splitting of S1 and increased loudness of both components
  • Loud, easily heard third heart sound (S3)
  • A sys­tolic murmur that intensifies on inspiration or expiration
  • Soft diastolic murmur
  • Mammary souffle- continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • A shift of the cardiac apex laterally
  • ECG changes: 
    • Left axis deviation
    • Q waves in leads 2, 3 and avF
    • Flat or inverted T waves in lead 3, V1-V3
  • Increased cardiac output, heart rate, and ejection fraction
  • Decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills 1 hour after initiating the transfusion. Direct antiglobulin test and plasma-free hemoglobin levels are negative. Antibodies against donor white blood cells and human leukocyte antigens are primarily implicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and chills during transfusion with no evidence of hemolysis as suggested by the negative direct antiglobulin test/Coombs test and negative plasma free hemoglobin is suggestive of a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR).

FNHTR is the most commonly occurring transfusion reaction that occurs between 1-6 hours after transfusion. During blood storage, leukocytes release cytokines, which when transfused can cause transient fevers, chills, and malaise without hemolysis.

The image below shows a leukoreduction filter which is used for filtering out donor WBCs.

This helps in reducing the incidence of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). They also remove microaggregates. 

Selective leukoreduction filters have been developed capable of at least a 3-log reduction of WBCs in blood components. These synthetic fiber filters remove WBCs by a combination of mesh density, chemical attraction, and active adhesion. To meet FDA criteria for leukocyte reduction, all RBC units must have less than 5 × 106 WBCs/U and at least 85% of the original red cell content.

Leukocyte reduction of RBC components is most often performed by blood collection centers within the first few days after collection using an integral or sterilely connected filtration system. Filtration before storage reduces WBC breakdown products in the blood component. The optimum time for performing leukoreduction is before storage, although, a less effective option is to perform leukoreduction after storage, just before transfusion. 

Reduction in leukocytes either by filtration or irradiation equally effective in reducing the incidence of alloantibody-mediated refractoriness, and leukoreduction significantly decreases the rate of alloimmunization compared to those receiving non-leukoreduced products

Potential benefits include reduced risk of: 

  • Sensitization to HLA antigens (important for transplant patients & preventing platelet refractoriness)
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR)
  • CMV transmission

Management of FNHTR:

  • Stop further transfusion
  • antipyretics like paracetamol
  • Use leukoreduced blood products

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text:
A mother brings her 11-year-old daughter to get vaccinated against the virus responsible for cervical cancer. On examination, the girl is otherwise healthy. Which of the following statements given below are incorrect?
  1. HPV 16 is the most common strain associated with cervical adenocarcinoma
  2. HPV 6 and HPV 11 are low-risk strains causing genital warts
  3. Vaccination is not recommended as the daughter is not at the sexually active age
  4. Cervarix gives additional protection against genital warts 
  5. Gardasil 9 gives additional protection against vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
questions.solution:
1, 3 and 4 are incorrect statements.

HPV is the primary infectious agent associated with cervical cancer.

HPV serotypes associated with cervical cancer

  • High-risk strains: HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 45 - Cause CIN and Invasive cervical cancer
  • Low-risk strains: HPV 6,11 - Cause genital warts/ condyloma acuminata
  • HPV 16 is the single most common HPV strain attributable to invasive cervical cancer cases (~57% of cases)
  • HPV 16 and HPV 18 are the most common strains associated with invasive cervical cancer cases (~73% of the cases)
  • HPV 16 is most commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix
  • HPV 18 is the most commonly associated with cervical adenocarcinoma

The HPV viral E6 and E7 oncoproteins play a role in malignant conversion by affecting the action of tumor suppressor genes. E6 binds to p53 gene protein and E7 binds to pRB (retinoblastoma tumor suppressor gene product) causing degradation of these suppressor proteins. 

Other risk factors for cervical cancer include:

  • Cigarette smoking
  • Increased parity
  • Sexual activity: Early age of first intercourse, > 6-lifetime sexual partners
  • Long-term use of combined OCPs
  • Immunosuppression/HIV infection

HPV vaccines are recommended as part of routine vaccination at the age of 11 or 12 years (vaccination can be begun at age 9). Vaccination is also recommended for everyone until 26 years of age if not adequately vaccinated previously. Sexual activity is not a criterion to start vaccination.

It can be given as a series of either two or three doses, depending on age at initial vaccination. In the recent IAP schedule, HPV vaccination has been included to be given as 2 doses at 6 months interval between 9-14 years; and as 3 doses for those aged 15 years or above.

Vaccines and protection against HPV strains 

  • The most common strains HPV 16 or 18 are targeted by all three vaccines.
  • Cervarix is bivalent and protects against HPV 16 and 18. (It does not protect against anogenital warts caused by HPV 6 and 11).
  • Gardasil is quadrivalent and additionally protects against HPV 6 and 11.
  • Gardasil-9 is nonavalent and protects against 9 strains which include five additional types: HPV 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58. This renders protection against VIN also. 

 

Vaccine Type Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil 9

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a painless beefy-red ulcer on the labia that bleeds when touched. There is no lymphadenopathy. Microscopic findings are shown below. What is the first-line management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy, with microscopy showing Donovan bodies points to a diagnosis of granuloma inguinale. It is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, also known as Klebsiella granulomatis. First line treatment is azithromycin 1 g orally on the first day followed by 500 mg daily.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

The image below shows a beefy-red ulcer characteristic of donovanosis.

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change.

Prolonged treatment with antibiotics is generally advised for donovanosis, usually for a minimum period of 6 weeks.

Treatment ladder for Donovanosis:

  • First line
    • Azithromycin 1 g orally on the first day followed by 500 mg daily
  • Second line
    • Doxycycline 100 mg orally on the first day followed by 100 mg twice daily, (or) 
    • Co‐trimoxazole 960 mg twice daily

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with lethargy, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. A  hematological malignancy was suspected. A peripheral smear showed cells positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase. Identify the correct CD marker and the cell of origin of this malignancy.
questions.solution:
Hematological malignancy with tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase-positive cells is most likely to be hairy cell leukemia. The cell of origin of hairy cell leukemia is the memory B cell. 

The markers expressed in hairy cell leukemia include the usual B-cell markers- CD-19 and 20, and specific markers such as CD 11c, CD 25, CD103, and annexin A1.

Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. These cells are called so because of the fine hair-like projections on their surface as shown below.

On peripheral blood smear, hairy cells have round or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with thread or bleb-like extension. In the bone marrow, these cells are usually trapped in a mesh of reticulin fibers and so it is difficult to aspirate and hence termed a dry tap. 

The classic hairy cells can be seen in the slide is shown below:

 

Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. There can be atypical monocytopenia due to which these patients experience an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

Other options:

Options A and D: CD 3 and CD 5 are markers of T cells.

Option C: Naive B cell is the cell of origin of mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-week history of a foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. There was one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this period. She has been mouth-breathing in her sleep for the past 4 days. Examination shows mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Which of the following is the instrument that would be used In the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a nasal foreign body. Clinically, patients with a nasal foreign body—especially children—present with a unilateral, purulent discharge that may sometimes be blood-stained. Tilley's forceps can be used to manage the condition.

Diagnosis is by direct visualization of the foreign body using a headlight, otoscope, or endoscopy.

The next best step in the management of this child is the removal of the foreign body either through positive pressure techniques or by instrumentation. Among the given options, Tilley's forceps would be the instrument of choice. It is also used for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint. The image below shows Tilley's forceps.

Asch's septum forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum.

Walsham forceps is used for disimpacting and reducing fractures of the nasal bone.

Citelli's forceps are used for punching bones and other tissues.

questions.text:
An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the TCA cycle. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of succinate to fumarate after adding malonate. Which of the following graphs represents the type of inhibition expected here?

V: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration
questions.solution:
The enzyme catalyzing the conversion of succinate to fumarate is succinate dehydrogenase. Its inhibition by malonate is a competitive inhibition which is represented by image 1. (option B)

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition. eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate.

The below graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/V is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

 

Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases

Although image 4 also corresponds to noncompetitive inhibition, the graph shows a plot of 1/V (Reaction Velocity) vs. concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate (S). Hence, it is a Dixon Plot.
