questions.text: In the following flowchart representing the natural history of disease, the duration between points A to B is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) act, 1971 with 2021 amendments?
  1. Consent of the husband is required for abortion
  2. MTP is legal in India for therapeutic, eugenic, humanitarian, and social reasons
  3. The opinion of one doctor is sufficient for abortions up to 24 weeks
  4. If abortion is conducted by an unlicensed person, he or she is liable for rigorous punishment for a period of 2 years, extendable up to 7 years
questions.solution:
Among the above-given statements, both the 2nd and 4th statements are true regarding Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: AQP4 IgG antibodies are positive in patients with __________.
questions.solution:
AQP4 IgG antibodies are positive in patients with Neuromyelitis Optica.

Neuromyelitis Optica, also known as Devic’s disease, is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis. Attacks of optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments.

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD):

Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated with AQP4-IgG

  1. At least 1 core clinical characteristic
  2. A positive test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method (cell-based assay)
  3. Exclusion of alternative diagnoses

Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated without AQP4-IgG or NMOSD with unknown AQP4-IgG Status

  1. At least 2 core clinical characteristics occurring as a result of one or more clinical attacks and meeting all of the following requirements:
    1. At least 1 core clinical characteristic must be optic neuritis, acute myelitis with LETM (Longitudinal Extensive Transverse Myelitis), or area postrema syndrome
    2. Dissemination in space (2 or more different clinical characteristics)
    3. Fulfillment of additional MRI requirements, as applicable
  2. A negative test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method or testing unavailable
  3. Exclusion of alternative diagnoses

 Core Clinical Characteristics:

1. Optic neuritis

2. Acute myelitis

3. Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting

4. Acute brainstem syndrome

5. Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions

6. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD-typical brain lesions

Additional MRI Requirements for NMOSD Without AQP4-IgG and NMOSD with Unknown AQP4-IgG Status

1. Acute optic neuritis: requires brain MRI showing (a) normal findings or only nonspecific white matter lesions, OR (b) optic nerve MRI with T2-hyperintense lesion of T1-weighted gadolinium-enhancing lesion extending over >1/2 optic nerve length or involving optic chiasma

2. Acute myelitis: requires associated intramedullary NMRI (nuclear MRI) lesion extending ≥3 contiguous segments (LETM) OR ≥3 contiguous segments of focal spinal cord atrophy in patients with a history compatible with acute myelitis

3. Area postrema syndrome requires associated dorsal medulla/area postrema lesions

4. Acute brainstem syndrome requires periependymal brainstem lesions

Drugs used in acute attacks: high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses: Mycophenolate Mofetil, rituximab, glucocorticoids with azathioprine.

The FDA has approved Satralizumab, a humanized IgG2 monoclonal antibody for the treatment of neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) in adults with particular antibody (patients who are anti-aquaporin-4 or AQP4 antibody-positive).

Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with cough, dyspnea, fever, and fatigue. On examination, inspiratory rales are present. A high-resolution CT image is given below. The lung biopsy showed characteristic Masson bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with cough, dyspnoea, fever, HRCT image showing characteristic reversed halo sign, and biopsy showing Masson bodies points to a probable diagnosis of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) is idiopathic interstitial pneumonia that typically involves elderly patients. It usually presents as mild flu-illness with fever, cough, and dyspnoea. On auscultation, inspiratory rales are usually present.

This disease can be sporadic or can also occur secondary to conditions such as connective tissue disorders (polymyositis) and malignancy.

High-resolution CT (HRCT) is the preferred imaging modality of choice. Patchy consolidation with a predominantly subpleural and/or peribronchial distribution is the most common finding. Some cases are associated with ground-glass opacity or crazy paving pattern. The characteristic reverse halo sign or atoll sign is highly specific but is seen in a few cases.


Histologically, COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and bronchioles, with foci of fibrosis. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycombing of the lung.


Treatment:

Corticosteroids provide substantial remission and are usually required to be continued for at least 6 months to avoid relapses. Cytotoxic (mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide) or biologic (rituximab) therapies can be helpful in both treating the disease and reducing the need for steroids.

Other options: 

Option A: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is the most common form of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia. It is a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown etiology occurring in adults and is associated with the histological or radiological pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

HRCT shows a patchy, predominantly peripheral, subpleural and basal reticular pattern. In advanced cases, honeycombing cysts and traction bronchiectasis may be present.

UIP has a poor prognosis and is generally refractive to treatment.

The below CT scan shows interstitial thickening, architectural distortion, honeycombing and bronchiectasis as seen in UIP.


Option B: Non-specific interstitial pneumonia is characterized by bilateral, subpleural, symmetrical ground glass reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. In contrast to UIP, honeycombing is uncommon and has a better prognosis. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis, but not as common as the UIP pattern. Management includes steroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, and rituximab with pulmonary rehabilitation.

Option D: Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. Histologically AIP presents histopathologically as diffuse alveolar damage. It is associated with high mortality.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding MMUs (Mobile Medical Units)?
  1. Lab investigations like hemoglobin estimation and pregnancy testing are available.
  2. Distribution of essential drugs is done from MMU.
  3. One MMU is approved for a district with a population of 5 lakhs.
  4. IEC (Information, education, and communication) sessions are conducted by MMUs.
  5. MMUs cover remote urban areas as well.
questions.solution:
The true statements about MMUs are 1, 2, 4, and 5.

Statement 3 is false- According to the current guidelines, 1 MMU is approved for a district with a population of 10 lakhs, and not 5 lakhs. This limit can be relaxed in tribal and hilly regions that are more inaccessible.

Mobile Medical Units (MMU) is a major initiative under NRHM to provide a range of healthcare services for people living in remote, inaccessible, un-served, and underserved areas in both rural as well as urban areas, with the aim of taking healthcare services to the doorsteps of such people.

The staff of MMUs includes:

  • Medical officer (MBBS only, preferably women): 1
  • GNM (General nursing and midwifery): 1
  • Lab Technician: 1
  • Pharmacist cum Administrative Assistant: 1
  • Driver cum Support Staff: 1

Clinical services are provided by a medical officer and team, whereas mobilization and outreach services are provided by ANMs and ASHA.

MMUs provide primary care services for common diseases (communicable and non-communicable), RCH services, screening tests, and referral to higher facilities and specialists as required. These include:

  • Provide point-of-care diagnostics: Blood glucose, pregnancy testing, urine microscopy, albumin and sugar, Hb, vision testing, and RDT for Malaria.
  • Collect sputum samples.
  • Screen populations over 35 for hypertension, diabetes, and cancers annually.
  • Undertake follow-up checks during the monthly visit and provide patients requiring drugs with a monthly supply (hypertension, diabetes, epilepsy)
  • Undertake IEC sessions on a range of health topics:
    • Improved preventive and promotive behaviors for maternal and child health, communicable diseases, including vector-borne diseases
    • Educate the community on lifestyle changes, the need for screening for NCDs, and early recognition and appropriate referral.

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

  1. Government-operated MMU
  2. Operation outsourcing to an external agency. However, capital expenditure, drugs, and supplies are provided by the Government.
  3. Both capital expenditure and operational expenditure are outsourced to an external agency. However, drugs and supplies are to be provided by the Government.

questions.text: A 65 years old male patient with a history of hypertension presented with an intracranial hemorrhage due to the rupture of the Charcot's artery. This artery is a striate branch of which of the following marked structure?
questions.solution:
Charcot's artery is the striate branch of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) which is marked as C in the above image. 

A- Superior cerebellar artery 

B- Posterior cerebral artery

C- Middle cerebral artery (MCA)

D- Anterior cerebral artery

 

The MCA arises from the internal carotid artery as the larger one of the two main terminal branches (the other being the anterior cerebral artery). Striate arteries are the small diameter branches of the MCA (and anterior cerebral artery) which penetrate into the cerebrum and supply the deeper structures.

Charcot-Bouchard aneurysms located in the lenticulostriate vessels of the basal ganglia are commonly associated with hypertension. Charcot's artery supplies the internal capsule and basal ganglia. It is also known as the 'Charcot's artery of cerebral hemorrhage'. 

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

Parts of Brain Arteries supplying it
Basal ganglia
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA
Internal capsule
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery (Recurrent artery of Heubner) - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior choroidal artery - a branch of ICA
Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery
Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Pons
  • Basilar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar arteries.
Medulla oblongata
  • Vertebral artery
  • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Cerebellum
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries

 

ACA - Anterior cerebral artery

MCA- Middle cerebral artery

PCA - Posterior cerebral artery

ICA - Internal carotid artery

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with widely distributed flaccid bullae. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acantholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence for immunoglobulin IgG is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding of bullae and the given histological features with a characteristic fish-net appearance in the immunofluorescence assay seen in the image are highly suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins (predominantly desmoglein 3). 

In pemphigus vulgaris, the location of the target antigen is intraepithelial. The bullae (blisters) of pemphigus vulgaris occur due to the destruction within the epidermis. Flaccid blisters are filled with clear fluid and may rupture, producing painful erosions.

This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present intercellularly. Direct immunofluorescence of skin samples with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis.

It occurs most commonly in middle-aged women, and the most common presentation of pemphigus vulgaris is oral lesions. Cutaneous lesions develop later, with lesions occuring most commonly on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back. 

They also show a positive Nikolsky sign, which is peeling off of the epidermis even on slight rubbing of the skin.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal
Immuno-fluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life threatening Resolves

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

 Dermatitis herpetiformis

Pemphigus vegetans

 Epidermolysis bullous acquisita
 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

According to Site

Intraepidermal

Sub-epidermal (Dermo-epidermal)

1. Subcorneal (granular layer)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Friction blister
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis

2. Spinous layer

  • Eczematous (atopic) dermatitis
  • HSV/VZV infection
  • Molluscum contagiosum
  • Familial benign pemphigus (Hailey-hailey disease)

3. Suprabasal

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Darrier’s disease

4. Basal layer

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis

2. Dermolytic (below basal lamina)

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans
  • Deep burns
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is Döhle body. Döhle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum seen in reactive neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles.

Döhle bodies, toxic granulations, and cytoplasmic vacuoles are some of the morphologic changes in neutrophils during sepsis, severe inflammatory disorders (eg: Kawasaki disease), and myelodysplastic syndromes.


Other options:

Option B: Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. They are seen in multiple myeloma.

Option A: Howell-jolly bodies are small nuclear remnants present in RBCs. Splenic macrophages are responsible for the excision of Howell-jolly bodies. Hence, they are seen in patients with asplenia and sickle cell anemia.

Option C: Heinz bodies are inclusion bodies in red blood cells composed of denatured hemoglobin. They are seen in glucose-6-phosphate deficiency.

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of foreign body sensation and dryness in his eyes. He has a history of multiple presentations to the hospital for prior eye infections. On examination, severe scarring and ulceration on the palpebral conjunctiva are noted however there are no follicles noted. Which McCallan stage can this be classified under?
questions.solution:
The presenting complaints and the examination findings showing scarring and ulceration on the palpebral conjunctiva without the presence of follicles are suggestive of stage IV trachoma as per McCallan classification. 

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

  • Stage 1 - Incipient - 
    • Clinical symptoms are not obvious
    • Clinical signs include immature follicles, mild punctate keratopathy, and occasionally pannus
  • Stage 2 - Established - 
    • 2a - florid superior tarsal follicular reaction with mature follicles
    • 2b - florid superior tarsal follicular reaction with marked papillary hyperplasia
  • Stage 3 - Cicatrising - 
    • Scarring along with the presence of follicles suggestive of persisting, active infection.
  • Stage 4 - Healed - 
    • Only marked scarring without the presence of follicles
    • Complications like severe dry eye, keratitis, corneal scarring, Herbert pits (scarred limbal follicles), corneal bacterial superinfection and ulceration may be seen

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: The below image shows the anterior view of the left scapula. What is the type of epiphysis shown by the part of scapula marked as "X"?
questions.solution:
The part of the scapula marked as "X" in the above image is the coracoid process. It fuses by an atavistic type of epiphysis.

The atavistic epiphysis is phylogenetically an independent bone in lower animals that becomes fused to another bone in man.

Examples:

  • The coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals
  • Os trigonum or lateral tubercle of talus

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula, and it projects forward and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament 
  • Pectoralis minor 
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament 
  • Glenocorocoid ligamnet 
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

The tip of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa, and can be palpated below the clavicle.

Parts of the scapula are given in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: You work in the Infection Control Committee of the hospital and are assigned the task of inspecting the disinfection and sterilization protocols of the operating room. What procedure should be followed to sterilize the urethroscope used?
questions.solution:
The sterilization of scopes such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes is done by plasma sterilization.

Plasma contains ions, electrons, and neutral particles. This state is produced by the application of radio frequency energy to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapors are passed. This generates plasma containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen which are used to sterilize articles such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes.

Other options :

Gamma radiation and ethylene oxide gas sterilization is used for the sterilization of articles such as syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves.

Autoclaving is used to sterilize surgical linens, culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut.

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine

questions.text: A G2P1 woman was diagnosed with placental accreta. Which of the following findings will be seen on the USG of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound imaging in a patient with placenta accreta shows large placental lacunae.

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

The following image shows the placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, then the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.

Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. This decidual deficiency then prevents normal placental separation after delivery.

It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

 

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Ring of fire appearance is seen on color doppler in ectopic pregnancy.

Option C: Thick myometrium with retroplacental clots is seen in TAS in abruptio placenta.

Option D: Snowstorm appearance is seen in TAS in molar pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is undergoing coronary thrombolysis and requires tenecteplase for fibrinolytic therapy. Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication to starting this drug?

choices.text: Ischemic stroke within the last 3 months

questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is used for fibrinolytic therapy. An active peptic ulcer is a relative contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy. Other options are absolute contraindications.

 Absolute Contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy:

  • Known malignant intracranial neoplasm
  • Prior intracranial hemorrhage
  • Ischemic stroke within the last 3 months
  • Known structural cerebral vascular lesion
  • Suspicion of aortic dissection
  • Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menstrual bleeding)
  • Significant closed head trauma or facial trauma within 3 months

Relative Contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy:

  • Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure >180 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure >110 mmHg)
  • Active peptic ulcer
  • Noncompressible vascular punctures
  • Traumatic or prolonged CPR or major surgery within 3 weeks
  • Recent (within 2–4 weeks) internal bleeding
  • For streptokinase: prior exposure (more than 5 days ago) or prior allergic reaction to streptokinase
  • Pregnancy
  • Current use of warfarin and INR >1.7

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with long-standing diabetes is posted for extracapsular cataract extraction. After primary capsulorhexis, the given lens is handed to the surgeon for implantation. Identify the incorrect statement regarding it.

choices.text: Rigid intraocular lens is made of PMMA
Haptics  hold the peripheral loops with the iris
Capsular bag fixation is an ideal method to fix these lens
It is inserted in the anterior chamber, in front of the iris

questions.solution:
The given image is of a modified C-loop type of intraocular lens. It is inserted in the posterior chamber, behind the iris. 

Modified C-loop is a type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL). They rest entirely behind the iris in the posterior chamber of the eye. The central part overlying the optic axis is known as the optic. The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are knowns as the haptics. They may be supported and fixed as - 

  • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method)
  • Ciliary sulcus fixation
  • Sclera fixation

Based on the material of manufacturing, the PCIOL can be: 

  • Rigid IOLs -  these are made of PMMA (poly methyl methacrylate)
  • Foldable IOLs - these are made of silicone, acrylic, hydrogel and Collamer
  • Rollable IOLs are ultra-thin IOLs - these are made of hydrogel.

Other types of IOL are:

Anterior Chamber IOL - 

  • Lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported at the angle of the anterior chamber
  • These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy
  • Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is the most commonly used ACIOL (image below)

Singh and Worst’s is a type of iris-claw lens.

  • The iris-supported lens is fixed with the help of sutures, loops, or claws.
  • These are associated with a high incidence of postoperative complications.

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt trauma to his abdomen while playing sports. CT scan showed retroperitoneal hematoma. Trauma to which zone of retroperitoneum should always be explored surgically?
questions.solution:
Zone 1 injury should always be treated surgically.

Retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma.

The image given below shows the different zones of the retroperitoneum.

Zone 1 Central Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control
Zone 2 Lateral Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization
Zone 3 Pelvic Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization

If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done.

Mattox maneuver is left medial visceral rotation to expose the aorta. The Cattell-Braasch maneuver is done by right medial visceral rotation to expose the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: Which of the following is most consistent with active viral replication in a patient with chronic hepatitis B infection?

choices.text: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgM positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative

questions.solution:
Chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication has the following serological findings: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, and Anti-HBe negative.

After a person is infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serologic marker to increase in level is HBsAg. It becomes detectable in the serum between 1-12 weeks. It becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once the HBsAg becomes undetectable, anti-HBs antibody starts rising in serum and remains detectable indefinitely thereafter. The gap between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is called the window period. If HBsAg persists beyond 6 months, it is likely to be chronic hepatitis B.

HBcAg is located inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. As a result, HBcAg is not commonly detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection since naked core particles are not found in the bloodstream. Conversely, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after the emergence of HBsAg, usually within 1-2 weeks. Anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker useful for the identification of HBV infection during the window period. Initially, the anti-HBc is of IgM variety, but in chronic infections, it is of IgG class.

HBeAg appears shortly after the appearance of HBsAg. Its appearance correlates with high levels of virus replication. Anti-HBe correlates with a period of lower infectivity. In chronic active hepatitis, HBeAg persists and anti-HBe does not appear.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with excruciating pain in her lips, gums, and cheeks for the past 6 months. The pain is usually triggered by talking and brushing her teeth. Each pain episode lasts for 1-2 minutes. On examination, there is no sensory loss over the face. All the following are the adverse effects of the first-line agent used for this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. All the options mentioned above are side effects of carbamazepine except for nephrolithiasis. Nephrolithiasis is a side effect of topiramate.

Trigeminal neuralgia is more common in females over 50 years. It is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory. Pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief.

This occurs spontaneously or is triggered by touch, a cold wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). No objective signs of sensory loss.

Carbamazepine is the first line of treatment. If carbamazepine is not effective then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used. 

Carbamazepine is an iminostilbine derivative. It blocks voltage-activated sodium channels, slowing their rate of recovery and limiting the repetitive firing of action potentials. It is used in the treatment of:

  • Focal seizures
  • Neuropathic pain associated with trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias.
  • Generalized, focal-to-bilateral, and idiopathic tonic-clonic seizures.

Side effects of carbamazepine therapy include: mnemonic: HEADS

  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Eosinophilia
  • Agranulocytosis: report symptoms like sore throat/fever
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Ataxia
  • Dilutional hyponatremia
  • Diplopia, blurred vision
  • Splenomegaly
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome

Note: Carbamazepine should not be used with clozapine as both cause agranulocytosis.

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with features of sepsis. Calculate the qSOFA score from the following findings.

GCS- 15/15
Respiratory rate- 24/min
BP- 90/60 mmHg
Platelet count - 1,00,000/cumm
Serum Creatinine- 1.2 mg/dL

qSOFA: Quick Sepsis Related Organ Failure Assessment
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the qSOFA score can be calculated as 2.

  • No altered mental status - 0
  • Respiratory rate is 24/min - 1
  • Systolic BP is 90 mmHg - 1 

qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/ sensorium (Glassgow coma scale <15)

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

Other findings are not included in qSOFA. 

SOFA score (Sequential organ failure assessment) is done to assess organ dysfunction or mortality from sepsis.

This includes:

  • Circulation - systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - bilirubin
  • Renal function - creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine
Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

Cardiovascular

Hypotension

 No hypotension

MAP <70 mmHg

Dopamine <5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ 

 Dopamine >5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ Dopamine >15 or epi/norepi >0.1¤ 

Coagulation

Platelets (×103 per μL)

 >150 ≤150 ≤100 ≤50  ≤20

Respiration

(PaO2/FIO2) (mm Hg)

 >400 ≤400 ≤300 ≤200 with respiratory support ≤100 with respiratory support

Mentation

GCS

 15 13–14 10–12 6–9 <6

Liver

Bilirubin(μmol/L)

 <20 20–32 33–101 102–204 >204

Kidney

Creatinine (μmol/L) or urine output

 <110 110–170 171–299 300–440 or <500 mL/day  >440 or <200 mL/day

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of warty cutaneous growth on the foot of the farmer and microscopic finding of sclerotic bodies suggests a diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. Clinical features include warty, cutaneous nodules which resemble the florets of a cauliflower, usually confined to feet and lower legs. 

Diagnosis is a histopathological examination of the lesions which show the presence of fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies as shown below.

Treatment:- Relapse is very common in this disease. Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. If surgery is not feasible or for larger lesions chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole is efficacious.

Other options:

Option A -  In sporotrichosis patients present with nodulo-ulcerative lesions which spread proximally along the lymphatics. Microscopy shows asteroid bodies. It can be seen as an oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. 

Option B - Mycetoma is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes). It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

The image below shows a mycetoma of the foot:

Option D - Phaeohyphomycosis: It is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions may be plaques that are verrucous, hyperkeratotic or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: Quintero staging is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Quintero staging is used in the grading of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV— frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—the demise of either fetus.

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome is a condition that affects multifetal pregnancies where there are shared placentas (monochorionic placentation). It occurs due to arteriovenous anastomoses occurring within the placenta. Unidirectional flow leads to the shunting of blood away from one twin and towards the other. 

The donor twin may have anemia, growth restriction, oliguria, oligohydramnios, and pallor. The recipient twin may have polycythemia, heart failure, circulatory overload (hydrops), plethoric appearance, severe hypervolemia, hyperviscosity, severe hyperbilirubinemia, and kernicterus.

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome.

Treatment:

  • Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS - Quintero stages 2 to 4.
  • Septostomy is seldom done. 
  • Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid.
  • Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.
  • Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) by Solomon technique is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and a reduced likelihood of recurrence.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, G2P1L1 at 33 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital for management of spontaneous preterm labor. What is the dose of dexamethasone administered to stimulate fetal lung maturation in her?
questions.solution:
The dose of dexamethasone administered to stimulate fetal lung maturation is 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), overall neonatal mortality, and neurodevelopmental impairment. 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. The dose of Betamethasone is 12 mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infections. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labour in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labour, and placental abruption.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, malaise, fatigue, and headache for the past 3 days. The peripheral blood smear examination is as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate resembling stereo headphones in appearance, are characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Hypnozoites are absent in P. falciparum infection.

Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the Plasmodium species transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. It is characterized by many nonspecific symptoms, including but not limited to tachycardia, tachypnea, chills, malaise, fatigue, diaphoresis (sweating), and headache. The fever of malaria is characterized by periodicity depending on the infective Plasmodium species. The fever returns every other day for Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum, and every three days for P. malariae. 

The peripheral smear finding of P. falciparum malaria are:

  • Normal size RBCs
  • Multiple ring form
  • Accole form
  • Absent schizont
  • Banana shaped gametocytes
  • Maurer's dots

The below image shows banana shaped gametocyte:

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner’s dots (Jame’s dots) Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax

questions.text: A man suffered from a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. What type of serological test is Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Nagler’s reaction done here is an example of neutralization test.

The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.


Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores. It is an anaerobe. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium. It grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis. The reverse CAMP test is positive with a hemolysis arrow pointing toward the Clostridial streak. Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the area marked 'x' in the image given below, you are likely to find all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises  1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. If the structure marked in red arrow is injured, which of the following clinical manifestations would you expect?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in red is identified to be the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). Injury to this nerve will result in loss of ankle eversion.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and ankle eversion
  • Diminishes sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved
  • High stepping gait is seen in this nerve injury

The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. 

It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The course of the common peroneal nerve is shown below.

Other options:

Plantar flexion is caused by the action of muscles gastrocnemius and soleus innervated by the tibial nerve. 

Ankle inversion is caused by the action of the tibialis posterior muscle innervated by the tibial nerve.

Ankle reflex (S1, S2) is characterised by the plantar flexion of the foot when the calcaneal tendon is struck with a percussion hammer. Thus it is lost in lesions of the tibial nerve.

questions.text:
You are a newly posted intern in the department of surgery. During your routine ward rounds, you notice a patient with an ulcer being treated with the following therapy. Which of the following statements are true regarding this modality of treatment?
  1. The therapy involves the application of continuous pressure of -250 mm of Hg
  2. It increases blood flow and decreases wound edema
  3. It creates a suitable bed for a flap or graft cover
  4. It consists of an airtight and sealed wound drain covered with an opaque adhesive film
  5. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy
questions.solution:
The image above shows the vacuum-assisted closure of an ulcer. The true statements regarding VAC are 2, 3, and 5.

VAC therapy is also called negative pressure wound closure. It creates an intermittent (not continuous) negative pressure of -125 mm Hg to promote the formation of healthy granulation tissue.

It is made up of foam with a perforated wound drain covered and plastered with transparent plastic/ adhesive film. It is commonly used in the management of pressure bed sores and diabetic ulcers. It creates a suitable niche and bed for harvesting flaps. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy. 

It acts by:

  • Reducing tissue edema
  • Clearing interstitial fluid
  • Improves perfusion and increases the healing process

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented with a burn injury. She is covered with burns on the front and back of her upper limbs and chest. She also has burns covering the front of both her lower limbs. Calculate the percentage of burns.
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 54% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

Calculation:

  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%  
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%
  • Burns on the front of both lower limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%

Therefore the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 18+18+18 = 54%.
