questions.text:
Match the components of angiogenesis to their respective actions:

Component

 Action
1. Vascular endothelial growth factor a. Smooth muscle cells recruiter
2.Fibroblast growth factor-2 b. Formation of vascular lumen
3. Angiopoietin c. Suppression of endothelial proliferation
4. Platelet-derived growth factor d. Proliferation of endothelial cells
5. Transforming growth factor - β e. Structural maturation
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Component Action
1. Vascular endothelial growth factor b. Formation of vascular lumen
2. Fibroblast growth factor-2  d. Proliferation of endothelial cells
3. Angiopoietin e. Structural maturation
4. Platelet-derived growth factor a. Smooth muscle cells recruiter
5. Transforming growth factor - β c. Suppression of endothelial proliferation

 

Angiogenesis refers to the formation of new blood vessels from existing ones. It aids in wound healing, establishing collateral circulation in ischemia, and helps in increasing tumor size. It involves various signaling pathways, cell-cell interactions, extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins, and tissue enzymes.

Mechanisms of angiogenesis are as follows:

  • VEGF: Promotes vasodilation by nitric oxide synthesis and subsequent formation of a vascular lumen. 
  • FGF (FGF-2): Induces proliferation of endothelial cells. It increases the migration of macrophages and fibroblasts to the site of injury. It also stimulates the migration of epithelial cells to cover epidermal wounds.
  • Angiopoietins 1 and 2: They are growth factors that are involved in the structural maturation of new vessels.
  • New vessels are stabilized by pericytes, smooth muscle cells, and by the deposition of connective tissue.
  • PDGF recruits smooth muscle cells.
  • TGF-β enhances the production of ECM proteins. TGF-β also suppresses endothelial proliferation and migration. 

Angiogenesis is regulated by the Notch signaling pathway. ECM proteins aid in angiogenesis by providing scaffolds for vessel growth. Matrix metalloproteinases degrade ECM to allow remodeling and extension of the vessel.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

Related Pearl: White cell peaks during wound healing

Cell Peak (day)
Neutrophils 2
Macrophages 3
Lymphocytes 7

questions.text: A term newborn with no risk factors does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The pediatrician starts effective chest compression at the rate of 3:1 after noticing that the heart rate is 58 beats/minute. The pediatrician again assesses the baby and now the heart rate was found to be 40 beats/minute. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat chest compressions following ventilatory corrective steps

questions.solution:
In the above-given scenario starting epinephrine IV is the next step in the management. For a term neonate with a heart rate <60 beats per minute even after effective chest compression, epinephrine IV should be started.

After the initial steps of neonatal resuscitation, the heart rate of the baby must be assessed. If the heart rate is <100 beats per minute (bpm), positive pressure ventilation should be initiated along with SPO2 monitoring to ensure adequate ventilation. 

If the heart rate remains at <100 bpm, ventilation corrective steps and/or endotracheal intubation must be considered. The ventilation corrective steps can be remembered with the mnemonic MRSOPA.

  1. Mask has to be reapplied 
  2. Reposition head
  3. Suction the secretions
  4. Open mouth slightly and ventilate
  5. Pressure is increased slightly
  6. Airway may be changed

Following that, If the heart rate is <60 bpm, chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3:1 (90 compressions:30 breaths).

If the heart rate remains <60 bpm, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then epinephrine (1:10,000 dilution at 0.1–0.3 mL/kg intravenously) should be administered. The dosage can be repeated every 3–5 minutes. Persistent bradycardia may indicate inadequate ventilation or severe cardiac compromise.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented with the following finding in his axilla. On wood's lamp examination, a characteristic coral pink fluorescence was seen. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image showing hyperpigmented lesion in axilla along with the coral red fluorescence seen under wood's lamp is suggestive of erythrasma. This condition is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum which is usually present as a normal human skin inhabitant.

Erythrasma is a chronic superficial infection of the intertriginous areas (axilla, anogenital regions, skin folds of breast, etc.) of the skin. The coral-red fluorescence of scales seen under wood's lamp is secondary to the production of porphyrin by the diphtheroids.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient complains of reduced mobility of the spine, hip, and knee joint pain. On examination, bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and ear cartilage was found. The thoracolumbar spine CT showed flattened & calcified intervertebral discs, and the urine sample turned black on standing. This condition is seen due to the deficiency of enzyme _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alkaptonuria, caused due to the deficiency of homogentisate oxidase enzyme.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/ homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue; generally occurs after the third decade of life and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs are pathognomonic. Other findings include degeneration of the intervertebral discs followed by disc calcification and eventually fusion of the vertebral bodies. Osteophyte formation and calcification of the intervertebral ligaments also occur.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs.

Other options:

Option A: Tyrosine transaminase deficiency causes type II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome). Patients present with painful corneal erosions with photophobia, learning disability, and palmoplantar keratosis.

Option C: Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency causes type I tyrosinemia (Tyrosinosis). Patients generally present with failure to thrive, neuropathy, boiled-cabbage urine, and liver failure secondary to cirrhosis.

Option D: 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability.

questions.text: The structure shown in the given image is found in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in all of the mentioned conditions except in schwannoma. 

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Meningioma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma

 

Verocay bodies are found in schwannomas. Antoni A area is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed Verocay bodies.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

questions.text: The device shown in the image can be used in children up to ______ months of age.
questions.solution:
The image given is of an infantometer which is a device used to record the length in children up to 24 months or 2 years of age. 

The infantometer consists of two vertical boards namely, a fixed headboard and a movable footboard. The steps involved in the measurement of the length of the baby include: 

  • The baby is placed in a supine position on the board
  • The infant's head is firmly held against a fixed upright headboard
  • Legs are straightened, keeping feet at right angles to legs, with toes pointing upward
  • The free footboard is brought into firm contact with the child's heels
  • The length of the baby is measured from a scale, which is set in the measuring table

Measurement of the length of a child lying on a mattress and/or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended. 

For children older than 2 years of age a stadiometer is used to measure their height. While measuring the height, the child is to stand upright such that heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head are brought in contact with the vertical surface of the stadiometer. The child is asked to look directly forwards and the headpiece is held firmly over the head to compress the hair.

Plotting the height and weight on a growth chart helps determine whether the child is in the normal range for their age and early identification of factors affecting growth. During infancy, growth charts can be plotted at vaccination visits. Later in childhood, it can be during visits for vaccination, minor illnesses, or during school health programs. 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18-24 months can be classified as: 

  • Physical development - motor development during this period includes improvements in balance and the child develops the ability to run and climb stairs. By 24 months, children attain half of the adult height. Head growth slows slightly, with 85% of adult head circumference achieved by the age of 2 years.
  • Cognitive development - object permanence is firmly established during this period and the toddlers demonstrate flexibility in problem-solving e.g., using a stick to obtain a toy that is out of reach, figuring out how to wind a mechanical toy.
  • Emotional development - toddlers looking in a mirror for the first time will reach for their own face rather than the mirror image if they notice something unusual on their nose. They begin to recognize when toys are broken and may hand them to their parents to fix.
  • Linguistic development - a child's vocabulary grows from 10-15 words at 18 months to between 50 and 100 words by 2 years. After acquiring a vocabulary of about 50 words, toddlers begin to combine them to make simple sentences. At this stage, toddlers understand 2-step commands, such as “Give me the ball and then get your shoes".

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Note : Infant weight approximately Doubles at 4-5 months , Triples by 1year and is 4 times by 2 years of age.

Weight gained with respect to birth weight

Age Weight
5 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

7-12 years

questions.text: A couple has come for pre-conceptional counseling to make a decision on pregnancy planning. The method of communication used for counseling to help the couple to make a decision about health is known as_________.
questions.solution:
The method of communication used for counselling, wherein a person is helped to make a health decision is known as the GATHER approach, e.g. contraceptive counselling. Expansion:

  • G- Greet
  • A- Ask
  • T- Tell options or give answers
  • H- Help in making choices
  • E- Explain everything about the decision
  • R- Return for follow-up

Other options:

Option A: Delphi method: It is a systematic interactive forecasting method which is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires, which are answered by experts in two or more rounds.

Option C: Spikes protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organised manner to patients and families.

Option D: Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task, skill, or procedure. It arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing’ and 'seeing is believing’ philosophies.

Related Pearl: Methods of Health Communication

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding the insertion of the tube shown below?

choices.text: Length to be inserted should be measured from tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Patient should be lying down with the neck extended
Severe obesity is an absolute contraindication

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a nasogastric tube/ Ryles tube. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to the ear to the xiphisternum.

NEX method:

  • Nose–Ear–Xiphisternum.
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend the tube to the earlobe, and then to the xiphisternum.

Indications:

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Identification of esophagus and stomach on chest X-ray
  • Administration of radiographic contrast to the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)
  • Gastric lavage cytology to identify cancer cells in gastric cancer patients
  • Gastric decompression
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Inserting a Ryle's tube:

Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • X-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

Approximate length: 120-125 cm

The markings indicate the traversing of the tube through various parts of the GIT:

  1. 40 cm: Cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm: Body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm: Pylorus
  4. 70 cm: Duodenum

Contraindications:

Absolute:

  • Severe midface trauma
  • Basilar skull fracture

Relative:

  • Coagulation abnormality
  • Severe obesity
  • Recent banding of esophageal varices
  • Severe kyphosis

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl, who is an alleged victim of rape was brought to you for examination. On the evaluation of the stains present over her clothes following findings as shown below were noted. What is the likely specimen detected from the stain?
  • pH: 7.4
  • Florence test: Negative
  • Kastle Meyer test: Positive
questions.solution:
A positive Kastle Meyer's (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain.

This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple colour indicates a positive test. 

Other options: 

Option A: The Florence test is used for the detection of choline secreted from the seminal vesicles. Since this test is negative, the sample cannot be semen.

Option C: Tests for urine samples include detecting the presence of urea, uric acid and creatinine.

Option D: Tests for saliva samples include the Phadebas test and radial diffusion by α-amylase activity on agar gel.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A patient in the post-operative ward is poorly compliant with the respiratory exercises and ends up developing respiratory failure as a result. What type of respiratory failure would this be classified as?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause of acute respiratory failure in this post-operative patient would be postoperative atelectasis. Postoperative atelectasis causes type 3 respiratory failure.

Type III respiratory failure

  • Results from lung atelectasis.
  • Since atelectasis occurs commonly in the perioperative period, this form is also called perioperative respiratory failure.
  • After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.
  • Treated by
    • Frequent changes in position
    • Chest physiotherapy
    • Upright positioning
    • Control of incisional and/or abdominal pain
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation - used to reverse regional atelectasis

Related Pearl: Types of Respiratory Failure

questions.text: A female came with complaints of bone and joint pain. NSAIDs were prescribed. After a few days, she presents again complaining of itchy vesiculobullous lesions healing to give a brownish discoloration over the face (upper lip area), as shown in the image. A fixed drug eruption is suspected. All of the following measures would be valid steps to treat her, except __________.
questions.solution:
Management of fixed drug eruption (FDE) involves stopping the offending drug and symptomatic treatment with systemic antihistamines and topical/systemic steroids. Cyclosporine has no role in the management of FDE. Acute-onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE. The time between drug intake and skin symptoms was, on average, two days which is consistent with the time of onset in the question stem.

Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. They are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location. But new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug. FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Paracetamol/ NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

  • NSAID-induced FDE - lips and genitals
  • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/ sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE - genitals
  • Metamizole‐induced FDE - trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine‐induced FDE - face

A strong differential diagnosis is post-chikungunya hyperpigmentation reaction of the centro-facial face seen on the nose and cheeks (so-called “chik sign”). However, this is not the answer because the pigmentary changes develop after the fever subsides and may persist for about 3 to 6 months. The question stem describes the onset of pigmentary changes after a few days. Also, these patients do not have any preceding erythema or eruption over the affected areas during the acute febrile phase.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with mild skeletal deformities and a corneal opacity. He had no signs of mental retardation. Investigations revealed L-Iduronidase enzyme deficiency. Dermatan sulfate is positive in the urine. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with L-iduronidase enzyme deficiency is suggestive of Scheie's Syndrome.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

Deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase results in a wide range of clinical involvement, from severe Hurler syndrome to mild Scheie syndrome. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

The Scheie syndrome (MPS I-S ) is a milder form of MPS-I. The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic (corneal clouding, glaucoma, and retinal degeneration) and cardiac involvement (aortic valve disease) might be present. In Scheie's Syndrome, dermatan sulfate is lost in the urine.

The Hurler syndrome (MPS I-H) is a severe progressive disorder with the involvement of multiple organs and tissues that results in premature death. Affected children usually present between 6-24 months of age. 

Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and perianal itching. The mother said she noticed a white thread like structure in the child's clothes. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perianal pruritis at night time, excoriation of the skin around the anus is suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. 

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. They are oviparous. Man acquires infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. 

At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus and lays its sticky eggs on the perianal skin. This leads to pruritus and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

Since pinworms are rarely released in feces, fecal examination is not useful in the diagnosis. The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane is attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass side and examined microscopically.The image given below shows the NIH swab.

 

 

Another method of demonstrating eggs is the scotch tape method. Here, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides, and transferred to a glass slide. A drop of toluene is added and examined under the microscope.The below image shows the scotch tape method.

 

The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

Frequent hand washing, fingernail cleaning, regular bathing, and frequent washing of night clothes, and bed linen should be done. Infection can be treated with pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, or mebendazole as single-dose therapy.

Other options:

Option B: Ascaris lumbricoides causes infection when the egg containing the infective rhabditiform larva is swallowed. The eggs hatch in the duodenum to release the rhabditiform larvae, which then migrate to the liver via the portal vein, heart, and then to the lungs, pass up the respiratory tract, and are swallowed. They finally develop into adults in the small intestine. Here, the gravid females lay eggs, which are shed via the feces, and the cycle repeats. Definitive diagnosis is by demonstration of eggs in feces. The life cycle is shown below.

 

Option C: Ancylostoma duodenale or hookworm infects a person by direct penetration of the skin by filariform larvae. They develop into adult worms in the small intestine. Segmented eggs are passed in feces and these develop into filariform larva in the soil. They can cause severe local itching, cutaneous larva migrans, and respiratory symptoms. Adult hookworm disease is characterized by anemia, epigastric pain, dyspepsia, vomiting, and reddish black stools. Diagnosis is by demonstration of eggs or larvae in feces. The life cycle is shown below.

Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis infection is by direct penetration of the skin by the filariform larva or by autoinfection. The larvae enter lay eggs in the small intestine mucosa. The eggs hatch and release rhabditiform larvae which pass through feces into the soil and start another cycle. External autoinfection occurs when the larvae penetrate the perianal skin. Internal autoinfection occurs in immunocompromised patients. Here, the larvae mature to the infective form in the bowel itself. Diagnosis is by demonstration of rhabditiform larvae in feces.

questions.text: Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody directed against integrin, used in the treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin.

Natalizumab is highly effective and reduces the attack rate of multiple sclerosis thus improving the severity of the disease (both clinical and MRI). Natalizumab is given as an injectable preparation. 

The major concern of natalizumab is the risk of the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is also a life-threatening condition developed from the JC virus infection. The risk of developing PML is higher in patients taking natalizumab associated with JC antibody positive. Therefore, natalizumab is recommended only for JC antibody-negative patients.

Other options:

Option A: Fingolimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate inhibitor. It reduces the attack rate and improves the disease severity in multiple sclerosis. It is given as oral preparation. The patients on fingolimod are at risk of developing macular edema and disseminated varicella-zoster infection.

Option B: Teriflunomide inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme, dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase present in de novo pyrimidine synthesis. It is given as oral preparation. The adverse effect includes Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It has teratogenicity and is considered a category X drug. 

Option C: Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule located on the surface of mature B cells. It is given as an intravenous preparation. It is associated with an increased risk of malignancy like breast cancer and infusion reactions.

questions.text: The given image is a histological section of which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a histological section of the epithelium of the urinary bladder also known as transitional epithelium (urothelium).

Urothelium has 4 -6 layers of thickness of cells extending from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. It is named transitional epithelium as it apparently changed from a stratified cuboidal epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium. It has 3 distinctive layers as follows:

  • Basal layer made of cuboidal cells which can regenerate.
  • Intermediate layer made of polygonal cells responsible for the stretch of the organ by flattening of cells.
  • Superficial layer made of umbrella-shaped multinucleated cells which are protective and impermeable.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A young girl presents with an abrasion over the forearm. On examination, it appears as a reddish-brown scab. The likely age of the abrasion is:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the abrasion appears as a reddish-brown scab, so the likely age of the abrasion is 2-3 days.

Age of abrasions:

Color of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish-brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish-black       4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off         After 7 days

An abrasion is the most superficial of injuries and does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis. A pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. However, the dermal papillae are corrugated in nature. Thus, many abrasions enter the dermis and bleeding commonly occurs.

Types of abrasions: 

  • Linear abrasions/ scratches - caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Examples - abrasion caused by nails, thorns, or the point of a sword or knife
  • Grazed/ sliding/ scrapping/ grinding abrasion/ brush burns - caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin. They are the most common type of abrasions
    • Examples - abrasion caused by falls, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint/ patterned abrasions - caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Examples - abrasion caused by tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction/ pressure abrasion - is caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis
    • Examples - abrasion caused by ligature marks around the neck in hanging

questions.text: During an autopsy of a man with a suspected case of poisoning, you observe the presence of a bitter almond odor. Which of the following electron transport chain (ETC) complexes may have been inhibited by this poison?

questions.text: A microbiology resident is using the Lowenstein-Jensen medium as a selective medium for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The presence of which of the following components makes it a selective medium?
questions.solution:
The presence of malachite green makes Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Contents of LJ medium:

  1. Egg: Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism.
  2. Malachite green: prevents the growth of contaminants.
  3. Mineral salt solution: Acts as a buffer.
  4. Glycerol: Source of carbon, favors the growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis.
  5. L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen.  

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious, and difficult to emulsify (rough, tough, buff). 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid culture media: Lowenstein–Jensen (A commonly used, egg-based, selective media).
  • Liquid culture media: Dubos' media, Middle Brook’s media. Virulent strains tend to form long serpentine cords in liquid media, while avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner.
  • Automated Culture Media: 
    • BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes
    • BacT/ALERT: A colorimetric method
    • BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He had headache, nausea, and vertigo after the accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is the cause of the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery
Shearing of the cortical bridging veins

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion with a midline shift are indicative of acute subdural hemorrhage. Most commonly, it results from the shearing of cortical bridging veins.  

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. The causes of SDH include trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, and battered baby syndrome. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages

  • Typically unilateral (85%). 
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

During the subacute phase with isodense lesions, the findings which are suggestive of subdural hematoma are gyral effacement and ventricular compression on the affected side and midline shift away from the affected side.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady presents with complaints of chronic back pain. On examination, kyphosis of the spine is noted. MRI of the spine is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the MRI findings showing decreased bone density with the biconcave appearance of vertebrae known as codfish vertebrae are suggestive of osteoporosis.

A patient with osteoporosis most commonly presents with chronic back pain or pathological fractures. They present with fractures that occur without any trauma or as a result of low-impact trauma. The commonly associated fractures are of the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), fractures of the hip, and fractures of the vertebrae. In severe cases, the fracture of vertebrae can cause kyphosis.

Diagnosis of osteoporosis is made by the T score. T score measures the patient's bone mineral density with that of a young adult. A score of ≤-2.5 is defined as osteoporosis.

The mainstay of treatment is to reduce the risk of fractures. The following medications can be useful in the treatment:

  • Bisphosphonates - They are the first line of medication. They reduce osteoclastic bone resorption and prevent bone loss. Eg. Zoledronate.
  • Denosumab - This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analog. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate - It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.

Other options:

Option A- Paget disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance as shown below.

 

Option B - Osteopetrosis is characterized by abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation. The skull base is uniformly radio-dense and radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the rugger-jersey appearance (shown in the image below).

Option C: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease of the spine and sacroiliac joint. It typically occurs in the age group 15-25 years with a male preponderance. Features include backache, stiffness, sciatica, and fixed flexion contracture. Radiographic findings show erosion of sacroiliac joints, squaring, and bridging of the vertebral body leading to a bamboo spine appearance (shown in the image below).

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: There is a structure that is related to the area marked "A" in the diagram. The same structure passes through the diaphragm.  At what vertebral level does it pass through the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
The diagram shown is of the right lung identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum and the area marked A is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung. It passes through the diaphragm at the T12 level (through the aortic hiatus).

The right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior:

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein  

The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiacophrenic vessels, and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation. 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly.

The diaphragm is a domed musculofibrous sheet that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities. It is supplied by the phrenic nerve whose root values are C3, C4, and C5.

The important openings in the diaphragm and structures that pass through them are given in the table below:

Opening/aperture Structures passing through them 
Aortic hiatus (T12)
  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Lymphatic trunks from the lower posterior thoracic wall
  • Azygos and Hemi-azygos veins
Oesophageal hiatus (T10)  
  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels
  • Lymphatic vessels
Caval opening (T8)
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right phrenic nerve
Lesser apertures Greater and lesser splanchnic nerves

 

The image given below shows the inferior view of the diaphragm.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who did not respond well to metformin therapy was started on dapagliflozin. Which of the following is not true about this drug?

SGLT2 - Sodium-glucose cotransporter - 2

choices.text: It increases risk of urinary tract infections
It acts by inhibiting SGLT-2 transporter on distal convoluted tubule
It increases the risk of fractures

questions.solution:
Dapagliflozin acts by inhibiting the SGLT2 transporter present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. SGLT2 transporter is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and not in the distal convoluted tubule.

The SGLT2 transporter present in the proximal segment of the renal tubule is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. Dapagliflozin acts by inhibiting this transporter resulting in glycosuria and decreasing the blood glucose level. This drug is effective orally. This drug also results in weight loss.

Dapagliflozin has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of heart failure in both diabetic and non-diabetic patients.

The common side effects of dapagliflozin include urinary tract infections, genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine, and also increased risk of fractures.

Other SGLT2 inhibitors include empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and ertugliflozin.

Empagliflozin has been found to decrease the risk of mortality from cardiovascular causes in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient suffers from a myocardial infarction. Laboratory investigations reveal that troponin is elevated as a result of myocardial cell death. Which of the following features would not be seen in the cells of this patient?
questions.solution:
The manner of cell death seen in a patient with myocardial infarction is necrosis. Cell shrinkage is seen in apoptosis. 

Necrosis occurs due to severe injury. It can occur due to ischemia, exposure to toxins, burns, chemical and physical injury, and conditions that cause proteases to leak out of cells and damage the surrounding tissue. 

It is characterized by denaturation of cellular proteins, leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, enzymatic digestion of the cell. 

Necrosis occurs when damage to the cell is severe and irreversible. This leads to the entrance of lysosomal enzymes into the cytoplasm causing digestion. The contents of the cells may also enter the extracellular space and damage the surrounding tissue via inflammation. 

Some molecules called damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) such as ATP, uric acid that is present within healthy cells but are released during severe cell injury. These molecules trigger macrophages leading to phagocytosis of debris and the production of inflammatory cytokines. 

Necrosis can lead to the leakage of intracellular proteins into the circulation. These proteins can be detected as part of diagnostic tests for specific organ injuries. Examples include troponins for cardiac cell death, alkaline phosphatase for bile duct epithelium, and transaminases for hepatocytes. 

Some morphological features of necrosis are as follows: 

  • Nuclear changes following one of three patterns:
    • Karyolysis - decreased basophilic nature of chromatin due to enzymatic degradation of DNA by endonucleases
    • Pyknosis - nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia
    • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Increase eosinophilia
  • Glassy homogenous appearance of the cell due to loss of glycogen
  • Myelin figures replacing dead cells that get further degraded
  • Discontinuities in plasma, organelle membranes
  • Dilation of mitochondria

The nucleus disappears within 1-2 days. 

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

Feature

Necrosis

Apoptosis

Active process

Enlarged (swelling)

Reduced (shrinkage)

Intact; may be released in apoptotic bodies

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate born to a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. Which of the following X-ray finding is characteristic of the most specific congenital heart disease associated with a baby born to a diabetic mother?
questions.solution:
The most specific congenital heart disease associated with a baby born to a diabetic mother is the transposition of great arteries (TGA). The characteristic X-ray finding of this condition is an egg-on-string appearance.

Egg-on-a-string appearance/ egg-on-side appearance refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg. Other chest X-ray features include mild cardiomegaly and a narrow mediastinum with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

ECHO is diagnostic. The size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus, the degree of mixing assessed, any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect, can be assessed by a color Doppler examination. 

Pathology of TGA:

 Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Because of this, the pulmonary and systemic circulations remain separate. The right side of the heart has deoxygenated blood and the left side of the heart has oxygenated blood. The pulmonary artery saturation is always higher than the aortic saturation.

The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Infants with transposition of the great arteries (TGA) are usually born at term, with cyanosis apparent within hours of birth.

 

Other options:

Option A: Box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex. 

Option B: Snowman heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Option C: Gooseneck sign: Seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defects.

1. Stellwag’s sign A. Lid lag
2. von Graefe's sign B. Infrequent blinking

The correctly matched option is option D: 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains of dull pain in the lower back for 8 months. He also complains of early morning stiffness which improves only on exercising. Ankylosing spondylitis is suspected. Which of the following is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of this disease, as per the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS) categorization criteria?

choices.text: Limited motion of the lumbar spine
X-ray of spine showing a bamboo appearance

questions.solution:
Sacroiliitis is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. The clinical presentation of a young male with backache, morning stiffness, redness of the eye, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. 

Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker (About 85 percent).

ASAS Categorization Criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients under 45 years of age with lower back pain of 3 months duration

Criteria comprise 2 sections: one ‘‘radiological section’’ and one ‘‘clinical section’’.

  • To qualify for the radiological section a sacroiliitis on simple radiography or MRI and at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis needs to be confirmed.
  • To qualify for the clinical section the patient needs to have a positive HLA B27 and at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis being mandatory

Radiological diagnosis of sacroiliitis 
      - Active (acute) inflammation in the MRI is highly suggestive of sacroiliitis due to spondyloarthritis 
      - Radiological sacroiliitis is defined according to the New York criteria (grade >2 bilateral or grade 3 - 4 unilateral)

Features of spondyloarthritis

  • Low inflammatory pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis
  • Uveítis
  • Dactylitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Crohn/colitis
  • Good response to NSAID
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA B27
  • High CRP levels

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine.
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints.

Extra-articular involvements are seen as the disease progresses.

  • Ocular - The most common extra-articular manifestation is anterior uveitis, typically unilateral, and recurs often
  • Pulmonary - Fibrosis of the upper lobe of the lungs
  • Cardiac - Acute aortic insufficiency, heart blocks
  • Gastrointestinal - inflammation of the ileum or colon
  • Dermatological - Psoriasis
  • Renal - Secondary IgA nephropathy
  • Peripheral joint involvement - shoulder and hips (presence indicates poor prognosis)

Complications that are likely to be seen due to this disease are -

  • Most common serious complication is spinal fracture. Lower cervical spine is the most common area for fracture
  • Loss of lumbar curvature (lumbar lordosis) causing limitation of movements in all directions
  • Gluteal muscle atrophy
  • Forward bending (kyphosis) of the thoracic spine leading to reduced chest movements and shallow breathing

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A male sewer worker had an on-and-off fever for 2 weeks, followed by jaundice, and purple-blue spots on his skin. He developed hematuria and neck stiffness soon after that and was found to have deranged hepatic and renal parameters. He succumbed to death. A  hepatic tissue section is stained as shown below. What special stain has been used to visualize the specimen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis caused by Leptospires which are best visualized in tissue sections by staining using Levaditi's silver impregnation method.

Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the blood or urine of an infected organism in a contaminated water body. It is a type of zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species. Rats are well-known reservoirs. 

The clinical picture varies from mild disease to severe fatal disease, referred to as Weil's disease. Signs and symptoms of leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, meningismus, hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury. Faget sign (temperature pulse dissociation) is also seen.

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. In the acute phase of the disease, leptospires can be seen in blood in the first week of infection. This is done with darkfield microscopy or immunofluorescence.

Leptospires should be treated with IV penicillin. Ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or doxycycline are alternatives for the treatment of severe leptospirosis.

Other options-

Option A: Albert's stain is used to demonstrate Corynebacteria with metachromatic granules. On staining with Albert stain, it shows delicate green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules. 

Option C: Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is commonly used for staining fungal cell walls. It stains the fungal wall black.

Option D: Loeffler’s methylene blue is used to stain the granules of Corynebacteria a bluish-purple color.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with complaints of hematuria. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had grade 5 chronic kidney disease. Auditory and ophthalmologic evaluation reveals sensorineural hearing loss and an anterior lenticonus.  Electron microscopy of the kidney biopsy reveals the given image. What is the type of collagen that is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) in electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome. Alport syndrome is a glomerular basement membrane disease that is caused due to mutations in the type IV collagen genes.

It is hereditary and can be inherited as an X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive disorder. However, the most common mode of inheritance of classic Alport syndrome is X-linked. Therefore, male relatives tend to be affected as in this case. 

Clinically, the classic variant of Alport syndrome presents with hematuria due to nephritis that slowly progresses to end-stage renal disease, an anterior lenticonus, and a mild, non-progressive sensorineural hearing loss that usually involves higher frequencies. Other eye findings include lens dislocation, corneal dystrophy, and posterior cataracts.

The investigation involves biopsy and histopathologic examination which includes the following findings-

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal until late in the disease course. End-stage renal disease can show histological features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
  • Electron microscopy: Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa producing a distinctive basket-weave appearance. 
  • Immunofluorescence: No deposits.

Other options:

Option B - Deficiency of type I collagen synthesis causes osteogenesis imperfecta. It presents as postnatal fractures, blue sclera, lax joints, fragile skeleton, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and normal stature.

Option C - Deficiency of type III collagen is associated with vascular type IV Ehler-Danlos syndrome. It presents as thin easily bruisable skin, arterial and uterine rupture, and joint hyperextensibility.

Option D - Deficiency of type II collagen is associated with skeletal dysplasia, ocular findings such as lens subluxation, cataract, myopia, etc, hearing impairment, and facial features.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray of the hand given below, what is the likely age of the person?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform (>10 years) but there is no fusion of the base of the 1st metacarpal (<17 years). Among the given options, the likely age of the person is <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is <17 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is >10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

Ossification Centres of Carpal Bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate: 2-4 months
  • Triquetral: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 3-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5-6 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be <18 years.

Related Pearl: Medico-legal importance of age

>5 years Criminal responsibility as per railways act.  
<7 years No criminal responsibility as per Section 82 IPC/ BNS Sec 20.      
10 years Abducting a child below 10 years for the sake of moveable property amounts to kidnap (369 IPC / Sec 97 BNS)
7 – 12 years Criminal responsibility if he/she is of sufficient maturity to understand and judge the nature and consequences of the act (Section 83 IPC/ Sec 21 BNS).
<12 years

Consent by the parent or guardian is needed before examination of the patient.

Not punishable under the Railway Act.
<14 years Cannot be employed in factory jobs. (Factory Act)
14 – 15 years Can be employed in nonhazardous factory jobs in the daytime.
>15 years Can be employed in any job
<16 years Taking away a boy without consent of parent or guardian amounts to kidnapping
<18 years
  • Juvenile (boy and girl) 
  • Taking away a girl without consent of parent or guardian amounts to kidnapping
  • Sexual intercourse with a girl with or without her consent amounts to rape (Section 375 IPC/ Sec 63 BNS)
>/=18 years 
  • Attainment of majority 
  • Can give valid consent to suffer any harm not known to cause death or grievous hurt. 
  • Valid consent given by a girl for sexual intercourse. 
  • Can make valid will. 
  • Legal age of marriage for girls.

questions.text: You have ordered a patch test for an 8-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis. When should you ask him to return for the final reading of the patch test?
questions.solution:
In patch testing, the final reading done for confirmation is done after 72-96 hours.

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning).

  • 48 hours: Patch removal for initial reading to detect delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation. 

Site - Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing, and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may falsely reduce positive test responses in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg of prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct inference from the following graph?
questions.solution:
The graph shown is a box and whisker plot, and option B represents the correct answer. 

A box and whisker plot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. The lines extending vertically from the boxes are known as whiskers and indicate variability outside the upper and lower quartiles.

It shows the five-number summary of a set of data including:

  • Minimum score
  • First (lower) quartile
  • Median
  • Third (upper) quartile and
  • Maximum score

 

In the box plot, a simple box extends from the 25th percentile (lower limit of the box) to the 75th percentile (upper limit of the box) and the line through the box indicates the median value (50th percentile). 

The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group excluding outliers.

Interpreting the box plot:

  • When the median is in the middle of the box, and the whiskers are about the same on both sides of the box i.e when each quartile is of the same length, then the distribution is symmetric or normal (as shown in box plot-1).
  • When the median is closer to the bottom of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the lower end of the box, then the distribution is positively skewed (skewed right as shown in boxplot-2).
  • When the median is closer to the top of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the upper end of the box, then the distribution is negatively skewed (skewed left as shown in boxplot-3).
  • Small circles or unfilled dots are drawn on the chart to indicate where suspected outliers lie. Filled circles are used for known outliers (as shown in boxplot-4 ).

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A patient was brought dead to the casualty. Fundoscopy exhibits the sign as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most accurate inference regarding the time of death?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows the Kevorkian sign. Hence, the most accurate time of death is less than 1 hour.

Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels and lasts for about 1 hour. This means that the patient had died within the preceding hour. 

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels and occurs due to loss of blood pressure. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized using an ophthalmoscope.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea: Dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled.
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous:  Linear increase up to 100 hours following death.
  • Tache noir: One of the post-mortem ocular signs. A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye which becomes brown and then black. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

The image given below shows Tache Noir:

questions.text:
Arrange the following photochemical changes of the visual cycle in the correct sequence:
  1. Scotopsin
  2. Lumirhodopsin
  3. Bathorhodopsin
  4. Metarhodopsin
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 3-2-4-1. Bathorhodopsin → lumirhodopsin → metarhodopsin → scotopsin.

The image given below shows the visual cycle.

Rhodopsin is the visual pigment in the outer segment of rods responsible for scotopic vision (night/ dark vision). It consists of opsin and 11-cis retinal.

The process of separation of rhodopsin into opsin and all-trans-retinal on exposure to light is called photodecomposition (rhodopsin bleaching).

When light is absorbed by rhodopsin, it decomposes very quickly. This leads to an instantaneous change of the cis form of retinal into an all-trans form. This all-trans-retinal separates from scotopsin to produce bathorhodopsin. Bathorhodopsin is very unstable and decays to form lumirhodopsin, which then decays and forms metarhodopsin I, metarhodopsin II, and finally, into the completely split products scotopsin and all-trans-retinal. 

Metarhodopsin II is also called activated rhodopsin, and it produces excitatory changes in the rods, which transmits optic nerve action potentials. to the central nervous system.

Re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal back into 11-cis retinal. This requires metabolic energy and is catalyzed by retinal isomerase. 11-cis retinal then recombines with scotopsin to form rhodopsin. Rhodopsin now remains stable until it is triggered by light energy to start decomposing again.

The equilibrium between the photodecomposition and rhodopsin regeneration is referred to as the visual cycle.

Role of vitamin A: The second route of re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal into all-trans-retinol, which is a form of vitamin A. All-trans-retinol is converted into 11- cis retinol by isomerase. 11-cis retinol is then converted into 11-cis retinal, combines with scotopsin, and forms new rhodopsin.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presented to the infertility clinic for semen analysis during which a hypoosmotic swelling test is done. What is the purpose of this test?

choices.text: To differentiate between normal and altered sperm morphology
To differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm

questions.solution:
During semen analysis, a hypoosmotic swelling test is done to differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

Unlike dead sperm, living sperm have the capability to maintain an osmotic gradient. Thus, when mixed with a hypoosmotic solution, living, nonmotile sperm with normal membrane function swell and coil as fluid is absorbed.

Semen abnormalities:

  • An acidic pH or lack of fructose indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.
  • A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation.
  • Oligospermia: A sperm concentration <15 million/ml, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.
  • Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in semen due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.
  • Teratospermia or teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology (Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis).

Sperm morphology is evaluated by looking at the sperm under a microscope and reporting the percentage of sperm with abnormal shapes. Morphology is evaluated using the WHO5 criteria.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text:
You inject lidocaine around a sebaceous cyst prior to excising. Which of the following processes contribute to its local anesthetic action?
  1. Inhibition of Na channel
  2. Potentiation of K channel
  3. Inhibition of K channel
  4. Potentiation of Ca channel
  5. Inhibition of Ca channel
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 5.

The mechanisms of action of local anesthetics like lidocaine include:

  • Inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels
  • Inhibition (not potentiation) of K and Ca channels
  • Inhibition of Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)

However, the main action of local anesthetics is mediated by the inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a left-sided temporal headache and jaw claudication. She has also recently been having fatigue, malaise, and a mild fever. Gentle pressure on the scalp elicits focal tenderness. ESR is elevated. Diagnosis is made based on a temporal artery biopsy. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of giant cell arteritis. Aortic aneurysms are commonly associated with this condition.

Giant Cell Arteritis - It is an inflammatory disroder of medium to large vessels and occurs due to infiltration of T cells and macrophages.

Clinical features - Constitutional symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and weight loss. Classically, headaches due to GCA are located over the temples. Other findings include jaw claudication, transient/permanent vision loss, and polymyalgia rheumatica which presents as the stiffness of the hips and shoulders. Additionally, large vessel involvement commonly presents as aneurysms of the aorta that may dissect. Large vessels like vertebral artery, aortic artery and ophthalmic artery are affected resulting in aortitis, aortic aneurysm, diplopia and sometimes complete loss of vision. 

Physical exam findings - Diminished pulses and discrepant blood pressure in the arms can occur and the temporal or other cranial arteries can be tender or thickened.

Diagnosis - ESR is generally highly elevated. A temporal artery biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis. Biopsy shows pan-arteritis, often most pronounced in the media, composed of CD4+ lymphocytes and macrophages

Treatment - The mainstay of treatment is glucocorticoids. Oral glucocorticoids may be tried if there is no visual loss but in the presence of visual loss IV glucocorticoid pulses must be administered.
