Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with right-sided large acoustic neuroma. On examination, there is hypoesthesia along the posterior meatal wall of the right ear. This is likely to be due to the involvement of _______.
questions.solution:
Hypoesthesia of the posterosuperior meatal wall is known as Hitzelberger's sign. It is seen in acoustic neuroma as sensory fibers of the facial nerve (VII nerve) will be affected. The posterior wall of the auditory canal receives sensory fibers of CN VII (through the auricular branch of the vagus) which is the reason for the manifestation.

Cranial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma:

Cranial nerve involved Clinical features
Vth nerve Reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of face
VIIth nerve Hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall (Hitzelberger’s sign), loss of taste, delayed blink reflex, and reduced lacrimation
IXth and Xth nerves Dysphagia and hoarseness

Nerve supply of External auditory canal:

  • Anterior wall and roof - the auriculotemporal branch of the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
  • Posterior wall and floor - the auricular branch of Vagus (Arnold's nerve). Cough response while cleaning the ear canal is mediated by the vagus which also supplies the larynx.
  • Posterior wall also receives sensory supply by the facial nerve (CN VII).

questions.text:
Match the following drugs based on their activity on the respective receptors with the corresponding plots on the dose-response curve given below.

A. β-Carboline

B. Salbutamol

C. Butorphanol

D. Naltrexone
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is option C: 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor.

Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.

Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor.

Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.

Graph 3 represents the antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own.

Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors

Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist.

Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.

The image given below shows the action of various types of selective receptor modulators.

questions.text: A narrow confidence interval corresponds to all of the following, except _________.
questions.solution:
A narrow confidence interval corresponds to a smaller standard error and not a larger standard error. 

Confidence interval = Mean ± 2 standard error. Therefore, a smaller standard error results in a narrower confidence interval.

Research is usually done with samples drawn from a population rather than by using the entire population. In order to get a fair idea of the population parameters, sample statistics and estimates of error in the sample are used to get a range of values. This range is the confidence interval (CI). It is estimated based on a desirable confidence level.

The confidence interval is calculated as the difference between upper and lower confidence limits. 

The width of the CI is an indication of the utility of our population parameter estimation. Factors affecting the width of the confidence interval include:

  • Desired confidence level: the width of the CI is directly proportional to the confidence level
  • Variability in the sample: the width of the CI is directly proportional to the variability in the data 
  • Sample size: the width of the CI is inversely related to the sample size

Therefore, increases in variability and confidence levels and decreases in sample size lead to wider confidence intervals. 

Standard error = SD/√ n, where SD is the standard deviation and n is the sample size. The standard error will reduce when the sample size is increased. Thus, the confidence interval will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size. 

Precision is the degree to which a particular value (such as an estimate of a population mean) is immune from random variation. A narrow confidence interval indicates more precision, while a wider confidence interval indicates less precision.

Related Pearl: Confidence Limits and Interval

Confidence limits are the upper and lower limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie.

Generally, 95% confidence limits are used and they are approximately equal to the sample mean plus or minus two standard errors, i.e., 95% confidence limits = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 standard errors.

The general formula is confidence limits = x̄ ± zσ x̄. 

  • Where z is 3 for 99.7% Cl
  • z is 2 for 95% Cl
  • z is 1 for 68% Cl

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval. Since the standard error will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size, the width of the confidence interval will also decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?

choices.text: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is started on tofacitinib. What is the mechanism of action for this drug?
questions.solution:
Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis, and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A patient experienced chest tightness, and breathlessness after going on a pilgrimage site which was at an altitude of 3574 m above sea level. He had ascended to that height in one day. During the initial period of acclimatization period, which of the following changes is most likely to occur?

choices.text: Shift of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right

questions.solution:
During the initial process of acclimatization to high altitudes, respiratory alkalosis occurs as a result of hyperventilation. 

The symptoms of chest tightness and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness, which can be prevented by gradual ascent with sufficient time for acclimatization.

Following are the physiological changes that occur during acclimatization:

  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation (hyperventilation). This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis. The initial state of alkalosis shifts the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left, which in later stages of acclimatization shifts to right due to increased 2,3 - DPG.
  • Increased erythropoietin secretion, leading to an increase in circulating red blood cells
  • Increased number of mitochondria
  • Increased myoglobin to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues
  • Increased tissue cytochrome oxidase
  • Increased sympathetic tone
  • Renal suppression of carbonic anhydrase and excretion of dilute alkaline urine brings the pH of the blood to normal
  • Decreased maximal exercise capacity (by ~1% for every 100 m gained above 1500 m) 

On the ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue, and the following symptoms are seen:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Treatment involves the administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude, and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presented with a hard, painless testicular lump with a dragging sensation on the left side. The blood investigations showed an elevated LDH. Which of the following is unlikely to be the cause of presenting complaints?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
LDH is unlikely to be elevated in teratoma. 

Raised LDH is seen in embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, seminoma, and choriocarcinoma.

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

Primary tumor (T)

The extent of the primary tumor is usually classified after radical orchiectomy (except for pTis and pT4) and, for this reason, a pathologic (p) stage is assigned.

questions.text: During a study, you are collecting, reviewing, and presenting information to answer a research question while making sure they meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. What is this process?
questions.solution:
The process of collecting, reviewing, and presenting information to answer a research question while making sure they meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria is called a systematic review.

 Steps of a systematic review:

  • Formulate the review question
  • Define inclusion and exclusion criteria to choose studies
  • Select studies and extract data
  • Analyze and interpret data

Other options:

Option A: Cohort study is a prospective study that involves the follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease.

Option B: Meta-analysis is a quantitative method to study the previous research studies of a selected topic/ research question. It uses statistical methods to summarise results and its validity relies upon the quality of the studies used and reviewed.

Option C: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention (maybe addition or omission of drug or actions) is given to a group of people participating in the study and compared to another group of individuals with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied.

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Evidence Pyramid in Research

The evidence pyramid gives the hierarchy or ranking of evidence from different types of methods used in research.

Animal research ranks the lowest, while meta-analysis ranks the highest and gives the best evidence.

questions.text: The following structure (arrowed) is marked during an anatomy practical exam. Which of the following structure contains the same type of white matter fiber present in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the corpus callosum which contains the commissural fibres. Among the given options, the commissure of the fornix/ Hippocampal commissure is made up of commissural fibres.

The locations of the commissural fibres are:

  • Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain
  • Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. 

The fornix has two types of fibres:

  • Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.
  • Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

It is supplied by the anterior communicating artery arising from the anterior cerebral artery. The fibres present in the fornix are association fibres except for the hippocampal commissure of the fornix which has commissural fibres. 

Uncinate fasciculus and the Cingulum contain long association fibres. Arcuate fasciculus/ U fibres have short association fibres. 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Helical CT is the gold standard investigation for nephrolithiasis.

HRCT is the investigation of choice for bronchiectasis. Bubble contrast echo can be used to demonstrate shunting. 

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

Radiolucent Renal Stones

  • Xanthine
  • Uric Acid (most common)

Drug induced renal stones

  • Triamterene
  • Indinavir

questions.text: Name the procedure for which the following set of instruments are used.
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments is used for dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).

 

Instrument 1 shows Muller's self-retaining lacrimal wound retractor. It is made up of two limbs with three curved pins on each for engaging the edges of the skin incision. The limbs are kept in a retracted position with the help of a fixing screw. It is used to retract the skin during surgery on the lacrimal sac e.g. dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) or dacryocystectomy (DCT).

 Instrument 2 shows Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator. It has a cylindrical corrugated metal handle with a conical pointed tip. It is used to dilate the punctum and canaliculus during syringing, probing, dacryocystography, DCT, and DCR procedures.

 Instrument 3 shows Bowman's lacrimal probe. It has blunt ends with a central stable platform. It is used to:

  • Probe the lacrimal gland in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction
  • Identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

 Instrument 4 shows lacrimal cannula. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. It is used for: 

  • Syringing the lacrimal passages
  • Injecting air, tryphan blue dye, pilocarpine, and balanced salt solution in the anterior chamber during intraocular surgery

Instrument 5 shows a bone punch. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. The upper blade has a small hole with a sharp cutting edge. The lower blade has a cup-like depression. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during DCR operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

Instrument 6 shows the chisel. It consists of a blade having a sharp-cutting straight edge with one surface bevelled. It has a long and stout handle. It is used to cut the bone during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 7 shows the hammer. It is a small steel hammer attached to a corrugated handle. It is used to hammer the chisel during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 8 shows the lacrimal sac dissector and curette. It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted. It is used to curette the lacrimal sac in lacrimal sac surgery.

Instrument 9 shows Freer's periosteum elevator. It has a rounded handle with two slightly curved, tear-drop tips. It is used for blunt debulking and lifting periosteum from bones in confined areas. It is used in endoscopic septoplasty and DCR.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the surgical anatomy relevant during a laparoscopic hernia repair?
  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
The correct option is option C: 

  • Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by vas deferens 
  • Medial border of the myopectineal orifice is bound by the lateral border of rectus abdominis

The triangle of doom is bounded by:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Below is the image of the triangle of doom.

The myopectineal orifice is an osseo-myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel that all groin hernias occur. It is bounded by:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

Below is the image of the myopectineal orifice.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps in diapedesis through the endothelium during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury. This process is aided by platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

The process of acute inflammation has 3 components: An increase in blood flow due to small vessel dilation, and increased permeability of the microvasculature to aid plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation and migrate to the site of injury to exert their effects.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

  • Lumen of the vessel to the endothelium:
    • Margination: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of stasis of blood flow.
    • Rolling: Leukocytes start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium.
    • Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. 
  • Transmigration of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium.
  • Migration towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues.

Selectins, integrins, and their ligands are the most important proteins involved in adhesion and migration. Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on endothelium, and P-selectins present in platelets and on the endothelium. 

The weak rolling action slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins. Chemokines that are produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This in turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.

This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.

Diapedesis occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis 

 

Related Pearl: Principal Mediators of Inflammation and Their Source

Mediator Source
Histamine Mast cells, basophils, platelets
Prostaglandins Mast cells, leukocytes
Leukotrienes Mast cells, leukocytes
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6) Macrophages, endothelial cells, mast cells
Chemokines Leukocytes, activated macrophages
Platelet-activating factor Leukocytes, mast cells
Complement Plasma (produced in liver)
Kinins Plasma (produced in liver)

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text:
Match the following joints with their types.
  1. Saddle joint
  2. Ellipsoid joint
  3. Plane joint
  4. Hinge joint
questions.solution:
Option C is correctly matched. 

1 Interphalangeal joint Hinge
2 Metacarpophalangeal joint Ellipsoid
3 First carpometacarpal joint Saddle
4 Intercarpal joint Plane

All the above are different types of synovial joints.

Except for the first carpometacarpal joint, all the other carpometacarpal joints are plane synovial joints.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text:
Match the following variants of tinea capitis infection with their classical examination findings.
Column A Column B
1. Kerion a. Yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts called scutula
2. Endothrix b. Thick crusted pus with sinus formation and matting of hair 
3. Favus c. Single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss 
4. Ectothrix d. Multiple black dots within the areas of alopecia
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Column A Column B
1. Kerion b. Thick crusted pus with sinus formation and matting of hair 
2. Endothrix d. Multiple black dots within the areas of alopecia
3. Favus a. Yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts called scutula  
4. Ectothrix c. Single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss 

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area along with sinus formation. 

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, M. canis, M. equinnum, and M. ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion - a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. It is commonly caused by T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Favus - is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by T. schoenleinii.

The image below shows the kerion variant of Tinea capitis.

 Below is an image of the endothrix variant.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

questions.text: A middle-aged diabetic farmer presents with decreased vision, redness, blurring of the eye, photophobia and lacrimation in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding with anterior chamber involvement. The ulcer scraping under microscopy revealed branched septate hyphae. Which of the following agents is preferred in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with the image depicting a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and thick hypopyon and the microscopic findings of branched, septate hyphae suggest mycotic keratitis caused by Aspergillus or Fusarium. The patient also has an anterior chamber extension. Thus the preferred treatment would be intrastromal voriconazole.

Mycotic or fungal keratitis is seen in tropical countries, rural areas, and immunocompromised individuals. It usually is caused by filamentous septate organisms such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, or yeasts such as Candida albicans.

They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks. Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but these are usually milder in comparison to bacterial ulcers. 

Some salient features that point toward the diagnosis of fungal corneal ulcers are:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery irregular margins
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessely's immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes. It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Satellite lesions
  • A thick, non-sterile hypopyon

 The image attached below shows the immune ring of Wessley.

The treatment usually consists of non-specific supportive treatment and specific treatment with antifungals. The non-specific treatment includes:

  • Atropine (1%) drops or ointment - it prevents complications like ciliary spasm posterior synechiae formation
  • Local heat

Specific treatment includes:

  • Topical drugs - 
    • Natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B drops are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium
    • Nystatin is effective against Candida
  • Systemic antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole are given orally if the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated or if endophthalmitis is suspected
  • In cases of suspected anterior chamber extensions, intracameral voriconazole can be given
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Removal of necrotic material by scraping with a spatula
    • Cauterization with pure carbolic acid or trichloracetic acid
    • Therapeutic keratoplasty 

Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal corneal ulcers because fungi which are usually symbiotic saprophytes under normal conditions become facultative pathogens in the presence of steroids and can cause perforation.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features is referred from a PHC with the following chest X-ray. His dyspnea is worsening and his vitals are suddenly deteriorating. Which of the following clinical findings is unlikely to be seen in the patient?

choices.text: Tympanic note on percussion on the right side
Decreased chest movements on the left side
Absence or decreased breath sounds on the left side

questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the left lung points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. Tympanic note on percussion would be seen on the left side.

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When there is a progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) it is called a tension pneumothorax. It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain.
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea.
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness).
  • Neck vein distention.
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury.
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side.
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge.
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line.
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to adjacent lung. 
  • Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen.
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph).

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine film (common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. 

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. It may be the only indication of a pneumothorax in such patients.

The below image is a plain chest x-ray AP view showing pneumothorax. A deep sulcus sign is seen (arrow):

questions.text: The histopathological slide obtained from the lungs of a patient who died from respiratory failure is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological slide shows Masson bodies which are seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is synonymous with the previously popular designation bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

Histologically COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycombing of lung. The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratory symptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that are visible on a chest x-ray as patchy consolidation.

Other options

Option A - CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It primarily affects the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis). It commonly affects neonates and immunocompromised people (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV- infected individuals). The histopathology slide below shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo - owl’s eye.

Option B - Giant cell pneumonia

Also known as Hecht's pneumonia, it is a fatal but rare complication of measles. It is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. The postmortem examination (autopsy) shows multinucleated giant cells or Warthin–Finkeldey giant cells lining the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs. The histopathology slide below shows giant cells.

Option C - Silicosis

It results from the inhalation of crystalline silica. The slide below shows a silicotic nodule characterised by a central area of whorled collagen fibres, with a more peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages and a rim of lymphocytes.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1 woman is infected by Treponema pallidum in the 10th week of her pregnancy. Which of the following statements are false?
  1. There is an increased risk of pre-term labor
  2. The placenta will be enlarged and pale
  3. The likelihood of infection of the fetus in successive pregnancies is more
  4. There is an increased risk of immune hydrops in infants
  5. The newborn will present with the Hutchinson triad
questions.solution:
The false statements are 3,4 and 5.

Maternal syphilis can cause fetal infection (congenital syphilis) by several routes, the most common being transplacental transmission, followed by a transmission during delivery or across the placental membranes. Early maternal syphilis has a higher transmission as compared to late syphilis. There may be endarteritis of the blood vessels and loss of arborization of the villi. The infection causes the placenta to become large and pale (Statement 2).

Up to 70 percent of women with maternal syphilis have an adverse outcome. The most common complications include preterm labor (Statement 1), spontaneous abortion, stillbirth, fetal death, non-immune hydrops (Statement 4), and fetal growth restriction.

Newborns can have features of infection such as jaundice, ascites, petechiae, purpura, pneumonia, myocarditis, and long bone involvement. Hutchinson triad is not seen in a newborn and usually becomes apparent around 2-5 years of age (Statement 5).

Kassowitz's rule is related to congenital syphilis. According to Kassowitz's rule, if a woman with untreated syphilis has a series of pregnancies, the likelihood of infection of the fetus in later pregnancies becomes less (Statement 3). Usually, only the first pregnancy is an abortion, the following pregnancy losses will be stillbirths, and later pregnancies will have alive babies with features of congenital syphilis.

Maternal syphilis in all trimesters should be treated with parenteral penicillin G in order to prevent the spread of infection to the fetus. The treatment of choice for congenital syphilis is penicillin.

Related Pearl: Features of congenital syphilis

questions.text: Which of the following devices is used to measure uterocervical length?
questions.solution:
Uterocervical length is measured using Sim's uterine sound which is marked as 3.

The normal length of the uterine cavity including the cervical canal is usually 6–7 cm. The uterocervical length is measured using Sim's uterine sound which helps to determine the lengths of various intra-uterine systems or intra-uterine devices to be used.

The image shows various instruments such as:

  1. Sims uterine curette - a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.
  2. Hegar dilator - a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
  3. Sims uterine sound - to measure the uterocervical length.
  4. Karman's cannula - used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula - used in hysterosalpingography.
  6. Rubin's cannula - used in hysterosalpingography.

The below image shows Sims's uterine sound.

 

The image of the coronal section showing different parts of the uterus is attached below.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with metabolic syndrome. Presence of which of the following additional symptoms in this patient constitutes a component of Syndrome Z?
questions.solution:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on the NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
  • Hypertension: Blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

Note: 

NCEP: ATP III - National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III.

questions.text: A normal-appearing woman presents to the hospital for primary amenorrhoea. The patient has female external genitalia, scant axillary hair, and an underdeveloped vagina. She has well-developed breasts. But her uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. She is found to have a 46, XY genotype. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis of the patient with the following features would be androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS).

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is most commonly due to defective androgen receptors. This leads to androgen resistance in genotypical males (46, XY). Patients with complete AIS have a female phenotype at birth with normal breast development, a short vagina, and scanty pubic and axillary hair. These individuals have normal breast development during puberty due to the abundant conversion of testosterone to estrogen. The uterus and fallopian tubes are absent since there is normal production of the anti-mullerian hormone.

Testes may be present in the labia, inguinal area or intra-abdominally. There is a risk of germ cell tumour arising from the testes and hence the gonads are usually removed. These patients are given adequate estrogen replacement to maintain breast development and bone mass.

Other options:

Option B: Persistent Mullerian duct syndrome is due to disorders of the anti-mullerian hormone and its receptors. These patients appear as males but have persistent uterus and fallopian tubes.

Option C: 5 alpha reductase deficiency is due to the inability of converting testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. The patient has ambiguous genitalia until puberty which then normalises due to the increased testosterone during puberty. These individuals will have normal male internal genitalia.

Option D: Ovotesticular disorder of sex development involves the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual. 

 

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room with adequate uterine contractions. The presenting part of the baby is two buttocks and the external genitalia as shown in the image below. Which of the following maneuver is used to deliver the extended legs of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image in which the presenting part is two buttocks and external genitalia are suggestive of a frank breech presentation. Pinard maneuver is used to deliver the extended legs in this presentation.

In frank breech presentation, thighs are flexed on the trunk, and legs are extended at the knees. The presenting part would be two buttocks and external genitalia. This maneuver will facilitate delivery of the legs, only after the fetal umbilicus has been reached.

The patient should be under general anesthesia. The palmar surface of the obstetrician is to be introduced facing the ventral surface of the fetus. The breech is pushed up at least to the level of the symphysis pubis. 

Middle and index fingers should apply pressure in the popliteal fossa and cause partial leg flexion. The head is flexed by the other hand abdominally i.e. externally. The foot is brought down by grasping at the ankle with internal fingers. The other leg is brought down in the same manner.

The image below shows Pinard’s maneuver:

 Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Frank breech: Breech with flexion at hip joints, extension at knee joints.
  • Complete breech: Breech with flexion at both hip joints, one or both knees at flexed.
  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extension at one or both hips, as a result, one or both feet or knees lie below the breech. Footling is a type of incomplete breech with one or both feet below the breech.

 

Other options: 

Ritgen maneuver:

Used in the assisted delivery of the head by extension in normal labor. If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region) while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

 

Lovset maneuver: It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

 

Burns Marshall method: It is used in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following techniques separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii?
questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii.

Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, the large molecules lag behind, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their stokes radii.

Ion exchange chromatography separates proteins in inverse order of the strength of their interactions with the stationary phase and is based on charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away. HbA1c (Glycated hemoglobin) is best measured using ion exchange chromatography.

Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. The high selectivity of affinity chromatography is caused by allowing the desired molecule to interact with the stationary phase and remain bound within the column in order to facilitate its separation from the undesired material, which will not interact and elute first.

Hydrophobic interaction Chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength.

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: A biochemist performed electrophoresis on lipoproteins during a study and the result obtained is shown below. The marked lipoprotein which has moved nearest to the anode is likely to be ______.
questions.solution:
On electrophoresis, HDL moves farthest on the electrophoretic plate towards the anode.

HDL has the highest electrophoretic mobility and the least percentage of lipid content. HDL particles are the densest with a high protein-to-lipid ratio. 

Chylomicron is the largest lipoprotein and has the most amount of triglycerides. Chylomicron particles have the lowest density and the largest size. They contain the highest percentage of lipids and the lowest percentage of protein.

The density of various lipoproteins and their electrophoretic mobility are shown in the images below:

Action

Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)

Carry endogenous triacylglycerol from the liver to peripheral organs

questions.text: An ICU patient with a central venous catheter developed sepsis. A bacterial skin commensal was found to be grown in the blood culture. Which of the following laboratory results is appropriate for the organism found in the blood culture?

choices.text: Catalase negative, coagulase negative, optochin sensitive
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive
Catalase negative, coagulase positive, bacitracin resistant

questions.solution:
Skin commensal responsible for catheter-related bloodstream infections are coagulase-negative Staphylococcus namely Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, and novobiocin sensitive.

Novobiocin sensitivity distinguishes S. epidermidis from S.saprophyticus.

questions.text:
The urine of the patient taking indapamide will have:
      Cl-    Urea    Mg2+     K+
    1.      ↑      ↓      ↓      ↑
    2.      ↓      ↑      ↓      ↑
    3.      ↑      ↓      ↑      ↑
    4.      ↑      ↓      ↑      ↓
questions.solution:
The correct option is option C i.e. the urine will have increased levels of chloride, magnesium, and potassium and decreased levels of urea. 

Indapamide is a thiazide diuretic that can cause increased loss of chloride, potassium, and magnesium and decreased excretion of urea in urine. Thus resulting in hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia as adverse effects.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT. This results in the loss of sodium, chloride, and water contributing to the diuretic effect.

The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia.

The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration also decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension

Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Diuretics Sodium Potassium Calcium
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors ↑ ↑↑ No change
Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: In order to diagnose deep vein thrombosis in a patient with varicose veins, the doctor after ruling out arterial occlusive disease wraps the patient's affected lower limb in an elastic bandage. The patient is then asked to walk around. The test performed here is?
questions.solution:
The test performed in the above clinical scenario is Perthe’s test.

In Perthe’s Test, the affected lower limb is wrapped in an elastic bandage, after ruling out arterial occlusive disease. The patient is then asked to walk around. Severe cramping pain arises if there is deep vein thrombosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Schwartz test - on tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. 

Option B: Modified Perthe’s test - A tourniquet is tied around the upper part of the thigh to prevent reflux down the vein and the patient is asked to walk around. In the presence of normal communicating and deep veins, the varicose veins will shrink. If there is any block, the veins will get more distended. 

Option D: Morrissey’s cough impulse test - The limb is elevated to empty the varicose veins. Now it is put to bed and the patient is asked to cough forcibly. An expansile cough impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if the saphenofemoral valve is incompetent. Similarly, a bruit may be heard on auscultation.

  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his mother and is diagnosed to have a schizotypal personality disorder. Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
Extreme sensitivity to rejection is unlikely to be seen in a person with a schizotypal personality disorder.

A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It is characterized by strange perceptions, disturbed thinking, and behaviour. They usually lack friends due to poor interpersonal relationships. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition. Antipsychotics are useful for ideas of reference and illusions. Antidepressants can be used when they have a depressive component.

Extreme sensitivity to rejection is the core clinical feature of an avoidant personality disorder. The patient leads a socially withdrawn life but with a strong desire for relationships.

Personality disorders are divided into three clusters:

  • Cluster A: Schizotypal, schizoid, and paranoid
  • Cluster B: Narcissistic, borderline, antisocial, and histrionic
  • Cluster C: Obsessive-compulsive, dependent, and avoidant

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of vascular remodeling during pregnancy in the correct order of occurrence:
  1. Cytotrophoblast infiltrates the spiral artery
  2. Endothelial lining and the muscular arterial wall are replaced with endovascular trophoblasts
  3. Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments
  4. Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to decidual segments
  5. Spiral arterioles are transformed into a low resistance, low pressure, and high flow system
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events occurring in vascular remodeling in pregnancy is 1-4-3-2-5 i.e.

  • Cytotrophoblast infiltrates the spiral artery
  • Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to decidual segments
  • Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments
  • Endothelial lining and the muscular arterial wall are replaced with endovascular trophoblasts
  • Spiral arterioles are transformed into a low resistance, low pressure, and high flow system

The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries. In the first wave of invasion (10–12 weeks), endovascular trophoblasts invade up to decidual segments. In the second wave (16–18 weeks), they invade up to the myometrial segments.

This vascular remodeling process replaces the endothelial lining and the muscular arterial wall with endovascular trophoblasts. This results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, thereby transforming them into a low resistance, low pressure, and high flow system. 

In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion. 

The basic pathology in preeclampsia is endothelial dysfunction leading to decreased nitric oxide production and vascular spasm. This leads to ischemic changes that result in necrosis, hemorrhage, and end-organ damage.

Changes leading to vasospasm and endothelial dysfunction include:

  • Reduced vasodilatory prostaglandin PGI2 and increased vasoconstrictor thromboxane (TXA2)
  • Reduced angiotensinase activity and increased sensitivity of vessels to angiotensin II, which is a vasopressor
  • Increased production of endothelin 1, a potent vasoconstrictor
  • Increased inflammatory mediators (tumor necrosis factor- α, interleukins) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) causing endothelial injury
  • Increased antiangiogenic factors like soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase I (SFlt-1) and soluble endoglin (sEng)

questions.text: A senior resident who is in charge of the labor ward asks you to perform cardiotocography(CTG) in a patient suspected of fetal head compression. Presence of which of the following features on CTG is suggestive of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fetal head compression may show early deceleration on cardiotocography.

Deceleration refers to a transient decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting for ≥15 seconds.

Types of decelerations:

  • Early decelerations (Type I Dips): Onset, nadir(lowest point), and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It suggests fetal head compression resulting in vagal nerve activation.
  • Late decelerations (Type II Dips): These begin after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction respectively. The peak occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over.
    It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.
  • Variable deceleration: It is associated with umbilical cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. It has an acceleration at the beginning and also at the end of the deceleration. These accelerations are described as the shoulders of the deceleration. It is the most common type of deceleration. 
  • Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline and it lasts > 2 min but < 10 min.
  • Sinusoidal pattern: It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting > 20 min, thus resembling a sine wave. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal hypoxia (acidosis). It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother.

Acceleration: Transient increase in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 seconds. It indicates a healthy fetus due to an intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity.

Prolonged acceleration is the abrupt increase in FHR to levels above the baseline and it lasts > 2 min but < 10 min. 

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with clinically significant macular edema secondary to non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy and was treated with pan-retinal photocoagulation. Despite this, she did not find any improvement in her symptoms. OCT was done and it showed vitreomacular traction with elevated fovea. What is the next best step in her management?

OCT: Ocular coherence tomography
questions.solution:
Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with the removal of the posterior hyaloid is the preferred management in diabetic macular edema with traction. 

Diabetic maculopathy or macular edema is characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the subretinal space. It can develop at any stage of diabetic retinopathy (DR), from mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). 

Clinically significant macular edema (CSME) is diagnosed when one of the following three are present on the slit lamp examination: 

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 microns of the foveal center
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 microns of the foveal center along with adjacent retinal thickening
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening ≥ 1 disc diameter, at least a part of which is within one disc diameter of the foveal center

For diagnosis and further deciding the treatment plan for the patients, OCT is routinely followed. It classifies DME into: 

  • Non-tractional variants are seen in cystoid macular edema, and spongy thickening of the macula, and are managed conservatively
  • Tractional DME has vitreomacular traction or thickened posterior hyaloid and is managed by surgical intervention

In vitreomacular traction, fibrovascular components leak from the vessels into the vitreous cavity and form fibrous bands. It increases the risk of tractional retinal detachment and can rapidly progress into stage 4 diabetic retinopathy.

Thus, surgical management by pars plana vitrectomy with removal of posterior hyaloid is indicated. Scleral buckling and internal tamponade with PPV are also done if the detachment includes the retina. 

The image below is of an OCT in a normal patient. 

The image below is an OCT showing vitreomacular traction. The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as indicated by the arrows. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion can also be seen at the site of traction.

Focal laser photocoagulation and pan-retinal photocoagulation are done in progressive diabetic retinopathy. They are contraindicated in tractional DME due to the risk of further injuries. Anti-VEGF agents like bevacizumab are not effective in vitreomacular traction.  

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with confusion, memory loss, and agitation. On examination, he is disoriented and horizontal nystagmus is noted. Which of the following enzyme markers can aid the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
The features of confusion, memory loss, and horizontal nystagmus in a chronic alcoholic are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused due to deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1). This can be diagnosed by erythrocyte transketolase assay.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a water-soluble vitamin, required for carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is its coenzyme form and is required for the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase 
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

Beriberi - anorexia, dyspepsia, heaviness, peripheral neuropathy, and weakness (dry beriberi) or with cardiovascular features like edema, palpitations, breathlessness, distended neck veins (wet beriberi)

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with chronic alcohol abuse which lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

Korsakoff's syndrome is a neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by confabulation and memory defects. Immediate memory is generally maintained but short-term memory is diminished.

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy. 

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State
