questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is brought with complaints of yellowish discoloration of the skin. The mother reports that the baby was born at 34 weeks of gestation and has a poor suckling reflex. The baby is suspected to have breastfeeding jaundice. Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in this baby?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremic dehydration is unlikely to be seen in this baby. Babies with breastfeeding jaundice usually have hypernatremic dehydration. 

Breastfeeding jaundice occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding and usually resolves once breastfeeding is adequate. Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant include:

  • Weight loss >7-10% of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours) (option A)
  • Delayed stooling (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day) (option C)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger (option D)

Insufficient milk intake could be due to insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation. Late preterms (34-36 weeks of gestation) usually have poorly developed suckling and swallowing patterns which can lead to insufficient milk syndrome. 

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed on demand.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old veteran army officer presents with difficulty in concentrating, increased forgetfulness, and repeated falls due to sluggish movement. He also complains of seeing recurrent red animal figures for a few weeks. Which of the following statements are true about the likely diagnosis?

1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness is observed

2. Disturbances in REM sleep are observed

3. Parkinsonism is not a feature of this disease

4. Cholinesterase inhibitors are used in the treatment of this disease
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of dementia associated with visual hallucinations is suggestive of Lewy body dementia. True statements mentioned above about this condition are 1,2 and 4.

Lewy body dementia is the second most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. It is characterized by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. Thus, they are classified under synucleinopathies.

The core clinical features are (the first three typically occur early and may persist throughout the course):

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations are typically well-formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behavior disorder may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rest tremor, rigidity).
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics - severe adverse reactions if treated with antipsychotics

Other features are mood disorders like depression, anxiety, and autonomic disturbances like orthostatic hypotension, and constipation.

The mainstay of treatment here is symptomatic management which includes cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, galantamine, or donepezil), atypical antipsychotics, and SSRIs. Highly potent typical antipsychotics like haloperidol are contraindicated in this condition due to extreme neuroleptic sensitivity.

The image given below shows immunohistochemistry showing positive staining (brown) for alpha-synuclein of an intraneural Lewy-body:

Related Pearl: Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of probable and possible dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

  • Essential for a diagnosis of DLB is dementia, defined as a progressive cognitive decline of sufficient magnitude to interfere with normal social or occupational functions, or with usual daily activities.
  • Prominent or persistent memory impairment may not necessarily occur in the early stages but is usually evident with progression.
  • Deficits on tests of attention, executive function, and visuoperceptual ability may be especially prominent and occur early.

Core clinical features (The first 3 typically occur early and may persist throughout the course.)

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  • REM sleep behavior disorder, which may precede cognitive decline.
  • One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism: these are bradykinesia (defined as slowness of movement and decrement in amplitude or speed), rest tremor, or rigidity.

Supportive clinical features:

  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotic agents; postural instability; repeated falls; syncope or other transient episodes of unresponsiveness; severe autonomic dysfunction, e.g., constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence; hypersomnia; hyposmia; hallucinations in other modalities; systematized delusions; apathy, anxiety, and depression.

Indicative biomarkers

  • Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia demonstrated by SPECT or PET.
  • Abnormal (low uptake) 123iodine-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy.
  • Polysomnographic confirmation of REM sleep without atonia.

Supportive biomarkers

  • Relative preservation of medial temporal lobe structures on CT/MRI scan.
  • Generalized low uptake on SPECT/PET perfusion/metabolism scan with reduced occipital activity ± the cingulate island sign on FDG-PET imaging.
  • Prominent posterior slow-wave activity on EEG with periodic fluctuations in the pre-alpha/ theta range.

A. Probable DLB can be diagnosed if:

  • Two or more core clinical features of DLB are present, with or without the presence of indicative biomarkers, or
  • Only one core clinical feature is present, but with one or more indicative biomarkers

Note: Probable DLB should not be diagnosed on the basis of biomarkers alone

B. Possible DLB can be diagnosed if:

  • Only one core clinical feature of DLB is present, with no indicative biomarker evidence, or
  • One or more indicative biomarkers is present but there are no core clinical features.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text:
The image given below shows the normal JVP waveform. Which of the following wave component is responsible for atrial filling during ventricular systole?

JVP - Jugular venous pressure
questions.solution:
The v-wave of the JVP waveform is responsible for the atrial filling during ventricular systole.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.

The illustration given below shows a normal JVP waveform.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole. 

 The illustration given below shows a Wiggers diagram that correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a venturi mask is ______.
questions.solution:
The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a venturi mask is 15 L/min.

Venturi mask is a high-flow, fixed-performance oxygen delivery system. The highest oxygen concentration (FiO2) delivered is 60% at a flow rate of 15 L/min. It works on the Bernoulli Principle, which states that in order to maintain a constant flow, a fluid must increase its velocity as it flows through a constriction.

It is used in patients who require greater FiO2 such as COPD patients, where it is important to provide controlled oxygenation. It is available in different colors, with the green valve venturi mask providing 60% FiO2. 

The illustration given below shows the Venturi mask.

The Hudson mask is also known as a simple face mask. It is a low-flow, variable-performance device. These provide an oxygen flow rate of up to 5-10 L/min and provide a variable FiO2. The body of the mask functions as a reservoir for both oxygen and expired carbon dioxide. It is used in patients who require oxygen therapy for shorter periods of time.

The illustration given below shows a Hudson face mask.

Conventional oxygen therapy includes all the devices that are used in routine practices. It includes nasal prongs, low-flow nasal cannula, or masks. It is the main supportive treatment administered to patients after planned extubation. 

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low-flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high-flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

The below image shows a nasal cannula, which delivers oxygen at 1-6 L/min.

The non-rebreather mask is used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air. It can deliver flow rates of 10-15 L/min. Thus maximum flow rate is 15 L/min.

It is used in patients with significant hypoxia, with relatively normal ventilation, such as victims of trauma or carbon monoxide exposure.

The image given below shows a non-rebreather mask.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a 2-month history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules in the skin over her arms. Her lymph node biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lesions?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a woman with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a history of cough, dry eyes, nodules in the skin over her arms, and non-caseating granulomas on lymph node biopsy points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. In this condition, Schaumann bodies can be seen on biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

 

Other options:

Option (A): Birbeck bodies are tennis racket-shaped structures found in the Langerhans cells of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (shown in the image below). Although it can occur in adults, it is seen more commonly in children. Lesions similar to seborrheic eruptions are seen on the back, scalp, and trunk.

 

Option (B): Asbestos bodies are seen in asbestosis, which is an occupational disease that causes diffuse fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. These bodies are asbestos fibers covered by iron-containing substances during phagocytosis. Initially, patients will have irregular densities in the lower lobes. The advanced disease will show a honeycomb pattern on a chest x-ray. 

Option (C): Ferruginous bodies are also seen in asbestosis. They are other inorganic particles that are covered by iron-containing substances. This iron is thought to be derived from ferritin within macrophages.

An asbestos body can be seen in the image below:

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to the ER with complaints of severe pain behind his chest bone associated with sweating and giddiness. He has a blood pressure of 86/54 mmHg. The electrocardiogram recorded is given below. Which of the following would be efficient management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG showing ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF are suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. His vitals shows that he has hypotension and hence, the efficient management in this situation would be a brisk administration of fluids to combat the cardiogenic shock that would set in, if untreated.

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior wall infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

Sublingual nitroglycerine, intravenous morphine, and intravenous furosemide can reduce the preload and hence should be avoided in an MI complicated by hypotension.

In the setting of inferior wall infarction, signs of cardiogenic shock should prompt the suspicion of a right ventricular infarction. And the same can be evidenced by ST elevation in the right precordial leads (V4R, V5R, V6R). The diagnosis of right ventricular MI is suspected in patients with inferior-wall MI, clear lung fields (no added sounds onauscultation), and shock. If a right ventricular infarction is suspected, avoid nitrates and increase volume to ensure adequate preload. The right ventricle has less myocardium than the left and relies on adequate preload to function properly. If the right ventricle is damaged, preload reduction from nitrates may result in significant hypotension.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: Match the marked parts with their correct structures of the primitive heart tube.

choices.text: A-Bulbus cordis, B-Truncus arteriosus, C-Primitive ventricle, D-Sinus venosus
A-Truncus arteriosus, B-Bulbus cordis, C-Primitive atrium, D-Sinus venosus
A-Primitive atrium, B-Primitive ventricle, C-Bulbus cordis, D-Truncus arteriosus
A-Sinus venosus, B-Primitive atrium, C-Bulbus cordis, D-Truncus arteriosus

questions.solution:
The correct match is 

A-Sinus venosus

B-Primitive atrium

C-Bulbus cordis

D-Truncus arteriosus

The 2 heart tubes formed in the cardiogenic area fuse, except at their caudal most end, to become an inverted Y-shaped structure. During this fusion, the central part of the heart tube expands to form the future outflow tract and ventricular regions. The caudal pole of the tube receives the venous drainage, while the cranial end pumps out blood into the arterial system. 

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

 

Heart tube and their derivatives 
 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 

 

  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)

 

  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of Right ventricle

 

  • Outflow tract of Right and Left ventricles

 

  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the Left ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits into Right and Left atrium

Development of the right atrium: It is formed from three main sources.

  • The right half of the primitive atrium
  • Absorption of the right half of AV canal
  • Absorption of the right horn of sinus venosus into the right half of the primitive atrium

Development of the left atrium: It is formed from three main sources.

  • The left half of the primitive atrial chamber
  • The left half of the AV canal
  • Absorbed proximal parts of the pulmonary veins

Development of the right and left ventricles:

  • The trabeculated part of the right ventricle is formed by the proximal third of the bulbus cordis. The trabeculated part of the left ventricle is formed by the primitive ventricle. 
  • The outflow parts such as the infundibulum of the right ventricle and aortic vestibule of the left ventricle are formed by the middle one-third of the bulbus cordis only, i.e. the conus.

questions.text: You evaluate a 60-year-old man who presented with difficulty in forming words. He can make noises and give expressions as if he understood the questions asked. Which of the Brodmann areas is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly man with difficulty in forming words and intact comprehension is suggestive of Broca's aphasia in which the Brodmann area 44 will be affected.

In Broca's aphasia/motor aphasia/non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their emotions.

Other options:

Option A: Area 4 corresponds to the primary motor area which is responsible for initiating and coordinating motor activities.

Option B: Area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's speech area which is responsible for the interpretation and understanding of verbal and written words. Lesions in this area will result in fluent aphasia in which the person talks with increased fluency with new words but is inappropriate to the context due to lack of interpretation. 

Option C: Area 42 corresponds to the primary auditory area responsible for the reception of various auditory stimuli.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency

Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text:
What is the GCS score of a road traffic accident victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?

GCS - Glasgow Coma Scale
questions.solution:
The GCS score based on the given clinical scenario is 7.

It is calculated as follows:

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decorticate posturing/ abnormal flexion  - 3 

In the decorticate posture, elbows, wrists, and fingers are flexed, and the legs are extended and rotated inward, as seen in the image.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess patients with a head injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A neonate who was apparently normal at birth is brought to the emergency department with complaints of bilious vomiting. An upper gastrointestinal barium study was done and the image is given below. Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows the corkscrew sign which is a characteristic radiographic finding in midgut volvulus.

Midgut volvulus is a complication of malrotation of the bowel and may result in proximal bowel obstruction. It can occur at any age but it is commonly seen in the first few months of life. The baby presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal pain, and failure to thrive.

Characteristic radiographic signs include:

  • Corkscrew sign - It is a barium meal study finding seen in midgut volvulus. It describes the spiraling of the duodenum and jejunum around the mesenteric vessels. 
    It has been identified as a diagnostic indicator of midgut volvulus.
  • Whirlpool sign - It is also known as the whirl sign. It is seen due to the rotation of the bowel around the mesentery leading to whorls of mesenteric vessels. It can be seen in ultrasound and CT scans.

The whirlpool sign on a CT is shown below:

Rigler's sign - It is also known as the double wall sign and it is an abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. Here, both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible. 

Coffee bean sign - It is also known as the kidney bean sign or the bent inner-tube sign. It is a plain abdominal radiograph finding in the sigmoid volvulus, shown below.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset central abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and several episodes of bloody diarrhea. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with acute mesenteric ischemia. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
An embolus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia.

Mesenteric ischemia may be acute or chronic. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is most likely affected. An embolus is the most common cause of SMA occlusion. Possible sources for SMA emboisation include:

  • Left atrium in atrial fibrillation
  • The left ventricle after mural myocardial infarction
  • Vegetations on mitral and aortic valves associated with endocarditis and
  • An atheromatous plaque from an aortic aneurysm.

Other causes of mesenteric ischemia include:

  • Atherosclerosis of mesenteric vessels
  • Vasculitides
  • Venous thrombosis in factor V Leiden mutation
  • Non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia due to alterations in splanchnic blood flow.

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings.

Associated clinical features include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and the passage of bloody stools.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is angiography, and management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a lurching gait. When the patient lifts one leg, you observe the patient standing as shown in the image below. Which of the following muscles are likely to be affected in him?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a positive Trendelenburg sign. The muscles likely to be affected in him are the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. The patients also have a characteristic lurching gait.

Mechanism of actions of Gluteus medius and minimus:

  • Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus act as the abductors of the hip joint. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb. 
  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: To demonstrate hypsarrhythmia in the EEG of a child with infantile spasms, you should perform the test during _______.
questions.solution:
Hypsarrhythmia is the typical interictal EEG finding, seen in patients with infantile spasm. 

Infantile spasm is an age-specific seizure disorder that predominantly occurs before the age of one. Some cases may be diagnosed late as this condition may be mistaken to be hyperirritability, exaggerated startle responses, and/or colic. 

The spasms involve the muscles of the neck, trunk, and extremities and are symmetric and synchronous. The various phases of spasms are:

  • Initial phasic contraction is sudden, brief, contractions of various muscle groups and lasts <2 seconds 
  • Tonic contraction phase is less intense and lasts up to 10 seconds

A motor arrest or a period of attenuated responsiveness may occur following the spasms and lasts up to 90 seconds. Deviation of the eyes, nystagmus, and change in respiratory pattern may be seen in some patients. Most patients develop neurodevelopmental delays. The triad of spasms, arrest of psychomotor development, and hypsarrhythmia is known as West syndrome. 

The image below depicts the spasms seen in infantile spasm. 

The electroencephalogram (EEG) in the interictal period shows hypsarrythmia. This finding is the defining feature of infantile spasms and is characterized by very high voltage, random, slow waves and spikes in all cortical areas. These spikes vary in duration and location. This finding may precede the onset of spasms. During the ictal period, the EEG generally shows a high-voltage slow-wave transient followed by a general attenuation of activity.

The EEG images given below show normal findings and hypsarrhythmia respectively. 

Other investigations recommended are neuroimaging with CT/MRI and metabolic and genetic testing may be done to identify the etiology. 

The major options for the treatment of include:

  • Hormonal therapy - ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone)
  • Antiseizure medication - vigabatrin. This is used if associated tuberous sclerosis is present.

questions.text: Both PT (prothrombin time) and PTT ( partial thromboplastin time) can be used to assess all of the following coagulation factors, except _______.
questions.solution:
Both PT and PTT can be used to assess factors II, V, and X. PT is used to assess the extrinsic pathway, therefore, it cannot be used to assess Factor VIII which is a part of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

Prothrombin time evaluates the extrinsic pathway, i.e, factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen. It measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin).

Causes of prolonged PT:

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs (vitamin K antagonists)
  • Liver disease, particularly obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Rarely, a previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect

Isolated prolonged prothrombin time occurs due to the deficiency of clotting factor VII.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma via the intrinsic pathway, i.e, factors XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

Causes of prolonged APTT:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII (since it is part of the extrinsic pathway)
  • APTT is also moderately prolonged in patients taking oral anticoagulant drugs and in the presence of vitamin K deficiency

APTT is also moderately prolonged in patients taking oral anticoagulant drugs and in the presence of vitamin K deficiency (in which factors II, VII, IX, and X will fail to activate). A patient with previously undiagnosed hemophilia or another congenital coagulation disorder can also present with an isolated prolonged APTT.

questions.text: Which of the following radiologic features of the bone tumor is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle are features of osteosarcoma, but can also be seen in any malignant lesion. Giant cell tumor (GCT) classically shows a soap bubble appearance.

The periosteal reaction in osteosarcoma is a typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on an X-ray as shown in the image below.

Soap bubble appearance of GCT is shown below.

questions.text:
Which of the following arteries are branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?
  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Iliolumbar artery
questions.solution:
The superior gluteal artery and iliolumbar artery are branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Superior gluteal artery
  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery
  • Inferior vesical artery 
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

questions.text: The marked phase in the cardiac muscle action potential mainly occurs due to ______.
questions.solution:
The marked phase in the cardiac action potential is phase 3. It occurs due to the efflux of potassium ions.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels (voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reaches about +20 mV. 
  • Phase 1 (initial repolarization): When the membrane potential reaches +20mV, the fast sodium channels close and the potassium channels open. The potassium ions leave the cell leading to a brief repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening slowly in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close, stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to the resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

The illustration given below shows action potential of cardiac muscle.

Differences in the cardiac and the skeletal muscles - The action potentials of the skeletal muscle are almost entirely caused by the sudden opening of large numbers of fast sodium channels. In cardiac muscle, it is mainly caused by fast sodium channels and L-type calcium channels (slow calcium channels).

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. Which of the following lines is disrupted in the radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior dislocation of the left hip joint, as the radiograph shows the following findings:

  • Break in Shenton's line - Loss of continuity of acetabulum with the femoral head
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • Left limb is adducted and internally rotated

The image given below shows posterior dislocation with disruption of Shenton's line.

Image below shows different lines used in diagnosis of various conditions of hip:

 

  • Shenton's line (Yellow line in the image) - A smooth curve formed by the inferior border of the neck of the femur with the superior margin of the obturator foramen.
  • Hilgenreiner's line (Red line in the image) is a horizontal line drawn along the lower borders of the triradiate cartilages of the pelvic bone. Perkin's line (Blue line in the image) is a line drawn perpendicular to Hilgenreiner's line along the lateral margin of the acetabular roof. Both these lines are used in the diagnosis of DDH (Developmental dysplasia of the hip).
  • Klein's line (Green line in the image) is a line drawn on the A-P view or frog lateral view of the hip X-ray along the superior border of the neck of the femur. Failure of Klein’s line to intersect with the epiphysis results in a positive Trethowan sign- seen in SCFE(slipped capital femoral epiphysis).

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation

  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with lesions over the skin as shown below. On examination, the lesions were dry, scaly, and slightly shiny, with moderately diminished sensation. Which type of leprosy do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with dry scaly lesions and moderately diminished sensation, with the image showing moderately hypo-esthetic annular plaques which are punched-out, is suggestive of the borderline type of leprosy.

Borderline (BB) leprosy is the most immunologically unstable type. The characteristic lesions of BB leprosy are annular plaques with well-demarcated, punched-out inner margins and sloping outer margins. They appear as large plaques with islands of clinically normal skin within the center, giving rise to a Swiss cheese appearance.


Other options:

Option A: Pure neuritic leprosy (PNL) is a rare variant of leprosy. It is characterized by the isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks in the absence of skin lesions.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Ridley Jopling Classification in Leprosy

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the image below?

choices.text: At least 2 adults are needed to kill a healthy male
The victim is attacked from behind
Two sticks are placed on either side of the neck
Neck is squeezed between the arm and forearm

questions.solution:
The image shows the tightening of a noose around the neck by twisting a rod within the ligature. This is called garrotting. Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown over the victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting with a lever. A single assailant can kill a healthy adult male (Option A) Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution (Spanish windlass).

Option C: Squeezing to death using sticks is called bansdola. The neck or the chest is squeezed between two sticks, one placed in front, and one behind. The neck may also be squeezed with a single stick in front if the victim is lying down.

Option D: Squeezing the neck with the arm and forearm is called mugging.

The image given below shows mugging.

questions.text:
A patient who tested positive for COVID-19 was prescribed remdesivir as a part of his treatment regimen. Which of the following statements are true regarding this drug?
  1. It is an RNA polymerase inhibitor
  2. It should be given in doses of 300 mg intravenously
  3. Patient has to be checked for hypersensitivity reactions
  4. It can decrease the levels of transaminases
  5. It is used in moderate to severe symptoms of Covid19 infection
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 5 are true regarding remdesivir.

Remdesivir is a nucleoside analog. Inside the cells, it is converted to nucleoside monophosphate, which is subsequently converted to nucleoside triphosphate. This metabolite inhibits viral replication by inhibiting the enzyme RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

According to the latest ICMR and AIIMS guidelines, it can be used in patients with moderate to severe COVID-19 infection requiring supplemental oxygen within 10 days of the onset of symptoms with no renal or hepatic dysfunction. 

Recommended dose: 200 mg IV on day 1 followed by 100 mg IV once a day for the next 4 days.

Adverse effects:

Following adverse effects have been reported with remdesivir:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions- changes in heart rate, fever, shortness of breath, wheezing, swelling of the lips, face, or throat, rash, sweating, or shivering. Slower infusion rates can prevent this complication.
  • Increased risk of elevation of transaminases.
  • The antiviral activity of remdesivir can reduce if it is co-administered with chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine.

questions.text: While calculating the CHA2DS2-VASc score in a patient with atrial fibrillation, you would assign a score of 2 in all of the following situations, except _____.
questions.solution:
History of diabetes is assigned a score of 1.

CHADS2-VASc score is used to determine the risk of stroke in a patient with atrial fibrillation.

Anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation:

Anticoagulation is indicated for patients with mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, previous history of stroke. In nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, the risk of stroke and the need for anticoagulation is assessed with the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

Anticoagulants that can be used include:

  • Vitamin K antagonist - Warfarin
  • Thrombin inhibitor - Dabigatran
  • Factor Xa inhibitors - Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, and Edoxaban

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with complaints of breathlessness. The doctor advises him to get lung function tests using a spirometer. The image given below shows normal lung volumes and capacities. Which of the following lung volumes cannot be measured using this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows the graph of various lung volumes and capacities. Residual volume (RV) which is marked as 6 cannot be measured using a spirometer.

The illustration given below shows normal lung volumes and capacities.

Any capacity that involves residual volume i.e., functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC) cannot be measured by a spirometer.

Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, it cannot be directly measured by spirometry.

To measure RV, we need to first measure FRC by the helium dilution technique and then calculate RV by subtracting expiratory reserve volume (ERV) from FRC.

RV = FRC - ERV.

A typical basic spirometer consists of a drum inverted over the chamber of water, along with a drum counterbalanced by a weight. When a person breathes into and out of the chamber, the drum rises and falls and recordings are made.

The illustration given below shows a typical basic spirometer.

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. It hence gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/ airway disease.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A 26-year-old who has 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of 3x2 cm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and of size less than 5 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely to be a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to wait and watch as most of the functional cysts regress within 6 months of identification.

Features of a functional cyst:

  • Related to temporary hormonal variation
  • Benign and rarely become complicated
  • Should be at least 3 cm but not more than 7 cm
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless hemorrhage occurs

questions.text: A patient came to casualty after he sustained an injury to his forearm. The X-ray finding is given below. Which of the following complications is unlikely to develop?
questions.solution:
Posterior interosseous nerve palsy (not anterior) is an associated complication of Monteggia fracture.

Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the ulna in its upper third with dislocation of the head of the radius. It is referred to as a treacherous lesion because the dislocation is easily missed, especially if the radiograph doesn't include the elbow joint. More commonly seen in children after a fall on an outstretched hand either in hyperpronation or hyperextension. 

Complications of Monteggia fracture include: 

  • Posterior interosseous nerve palsy
  • Cubitus valgus deformity
  • Myositis ossificans
  • Malunion of ulna fracture
  • Non-union of ulna fracture
  • Synostosis between the radial head and proximal ulna
  • Proximal migration of the radius
  • Dislocation of inferior radioulnar joint

X-ray forearm must include both elbow and wrist joint and is done in AP, lateral and oblique views. McLaughlin’s line is used to diagnose dislocation of radial head. McLaughlin’s line is a straight line drawn along the center of the shaft of radius that cuts the capitulum irrespective of the position of the elbow.

In children, John Wein’s classification is used as it takes into account the greenstick fractures. In adults Bado’s classification classifies it into four types.

  • Type 1: Anterior radial head dislocation. (most common)
  • Type 2: Posterior radial head dislocation.
  • Type 3: Lateral radial head dislocation.
  • Type 4: Associated fracture of the radius.

 

Conservative approach is successful in children. Adults require open reduction and internal fixation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus 
  • Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 
  • Monteggia fracture in adults
  • Intra-articular fractures

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

questions.text:
Which of the following would be considered high risk as per the Risk-based screening strategy for GDM?
  1. Severe obesity
  2. Strong family history of type 2 diabetes
  3. Previous history of GDM
  4. Previous history of impaired glucose metabolism 
  5. Previous history of glucosuria
questions.solution:
The following would be considered high risk as per the risk-based screening strategy for GDM:

  • Severe obesity
  • Strong family history of type 2 diabetes
  • Previous history of GDM
  • Previous history of impaired glucose metabolism 
  • Previous history of glucosuria

If one or more of these are present, blood glucose testing should be made. Oral glucose tolerance test is routinely used to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus.  

Related Pearl: ADA criteria for Diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus

Any one of the following:

  • Symptoms of diabetes plus Random Blood Glucose concentration ≥ 200 mg/dL.
  • Fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.
  • Haemoglobin A1c ≥6.5%
  • 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an oral glucose tolerance test.

Note: In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia and acute metabolic decompensation, these criteria should be confirmed by repeat testing on a different day.

questions.text: A woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.  She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic.  Urine Rothera's test is positive. Which of the following tissues cannot utilize the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased here is ketone bodies and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  • β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  • Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  • Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

  • Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.
  • Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside
  • Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta hydroxy butyrate. 

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: A scientist is trying to develop a drug for a genetic condition. He seeks a drug that could cause epigenetic alteration in the DNA and could prevent the disease or seemingly improve the condition. All the following would include epigenetic modifications, except _______.

choices.text: Altering the gene sequence of DNA
DNA methylation at CpG islands in promoter regions

questions.solution:
Epigenetic changes are heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. They alter gene expression without mutation.

The term “epigenetics” means “above genetics.” It refers to the regulatory mechanisms that do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather change the expression patterns, or function, of the DNA. Epigenetic mechanisms play key roles in the establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. It can cause both gene activation and inactivation.

Epigenetic modifications include

  1. DNA methylation- It is the covalent addition and subtraction of a methyl group to DNA. Methylation is typically done in cytosine preceding a guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. CpG islands are mainly present in the promoter region.
  2. Histone modifications such as acetylation, deacetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, etc. Acetylation of histone activates transcription, while deacetylation represses transcription.
  3. miRNA- micro RNA or miRNA are approximately 22 nucleotides long. They do not code. They bind to mRNA and inhibit its translation.

Clinical significance of epigenetic mechanisms:

  • Epigenetic modifications, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, are reversible, which makes them amenable for application in therapeutic intervention.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and DNA methylation inhibitors are being tested in the treatment of cancer. These agents inhibit transcriptional silencing and thus reverse the chromatin condensation in cancer cells.
  • These modifications include heritable changes such as X-inactivation and genomic imprinting, but they can also result from dynamic post-translational protein modifications in response to environmental influences such as diet, age, and drugs.

Related Pearl: Role of Histones

Types

Function

H1 histones

Stabilize the 30-nm chromatin fiber

H2 histones

H2A–H2B dimers stabilize the primary particle and firmly bind two additional half-turns of DNA

H3 histones

(H3–H4)2 tetramer has a central role in the formation

of the nucleosome

H4 histones

questions.text: One unit of blood is collected from a blood donor. Which of the following methods of processing helps in the reduction of post-transfusion fever and chills in the recipient?
questions.solution:
Deleukocytation helps in the reduction of post-transfusion fever and chills in the recipient. It refers to a reduction of leukocytes in the collected blood sample to <1-5*106 leukocytes per unit.

Deleukocytation may be done in red blood cell concentrate (RBCC), platelets, plasma, granulocyte concentrates and whole blood. It can be done by initial whole blood filtration or RBC/ platelet elective filtration.

Other options:

Option B: Cryopreservation extends shelf life and so, helps in the availability of platelets and RBCCs of rare blood groups.

Option C: Irradiation is done to reduce graft versus host disease (GVHD).

Option D: Ultraviolet (UV) illumination is done to reduce transfusion-transmitted infections and to prevent GVHD.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension for 2 years came with complaints of easy fatiguability and shortness of breath. On examination, her sclera was yellow. Hemoglobin was reduced to 6 g/dL. On peripheral smear, spherocytes were seen. Further, a positive Coombs test was obtained. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is the most likely cause of the symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
The antihypertensive that is the most likely cause of the symptoms in this patient is methyldopa. All the above options are examples of centrally-acting sympatholytic drugs.

Some patients who are on methyldopa for prolonged periods break tolerance in some unknown manner and lead to the production of antibodies against red cell antigens, particularly Rh antigens. These antibodies give a positive Coombs test and sometimes result in significant hemolytic anemia. The onset is often abrupt and leads to a sudden drop in hemoglobin levels. This excessive hemolysis will result in jaundice and hemoglobinuria. The blood picture shows spherocytes and fragmented RBCs.

Methyldopa, a prodrug (an analog of DOPA) gets metabolized to α-methylnorepinephrine (the active metabolite). α-Methylnorepinephrine inhibits the adrenergic neuronal outflow from the brainstem via acting as an agonist at α2 adrenergic receptors in the presynaptic membrane in the brainstem. This attenuates the release of norepinephrine, thereby reducing the sympathetic output from the brainstem resulting in the reduction of blood pressure.

Therapeutic uses: usually used in hypertension in pregnancy.

Adverse effects:

  • Dry mouth, sedation
  • Gynecomastia
  • Positive Coombs test- if the patient is symptomatic, then stop the drug
  • Rare adverse effects- red cell aplasia, thrombocytopenia, lupus-like syndrome, etc

Other options:

Option A) Clonidine: It is an imidazoline derivative and acts as an agonist at α2 receptors. The mechanism of action is the same as that of methyldopa.

Therapeutic uses:

  • Hypertension
  • Diarrhea in diabetic patients
  • Opioid, tobacco, alcohol withdrawal
  • Menopausal hot flushes

Adverse effects: 

  • Dry mouth, sedation
  • Depression
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Clonidine withdrawal reaction

Option C) Moxonidine: It is a mixed α2 receptor and imidazole, I1 receptor agonist. It reduces the sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system thereby reducing blood pressure.

Therapeutic uses: Hypertension, neuropathic pain

Option D) Guanfacine: It is a more selective α2 agonist. It reduces the sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system thereby reducing blood pressure.

questions.text:
Match the enzyme with the disease caused by its deficiency.
           Enzyme          Disease
 1. Glucose-6-phosphatase a. Cori's disease
 2. Muscle phosphofructokinase b. McArdle's disease 
 3. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase c. von Gierke disease
 4. Glycogen debranching enzyme d. Tarui's disease
questions.solution:
Enzyme          Disease
1. Glucose-6-phosphatase

c. von Gierke disease
2. Muscle phosphofructokinase

d. Tarui's 
3. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

b. McArdle disease 
4. Glycogen debranching enzyme

a. Cori's disease

Von Gierke disease (Type Ia glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. Patients present commonly by 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia (leading to seizures), lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. Affected children often have a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly. The kidneys are also enlarged, whereas the spleen and heart are not involved. Laboratory findings include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria.

McArdle disease (Type V glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency. It appears in late childhood or the second decade of life. The typical manifestations are muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency is seen in Cori's disease (type III glycogen storage disorder). Failure to debranch glycogen into glucose subunits results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains which resemble limit dextrin. These children present with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, short stature, variable skeletal myopathy, and variable cardiomyopathy.

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

(Limit dextrinosis)

questions.text: A high school graduate went to the army recruitment drive but was not selected because of his flat foot. This condition is caused due to the involvement of which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
A flat foot is caused due to the involvement of the spring ligament.

Pes planus or flat foot is caused to due the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and can be either congenital or acquired. Its causes include rupture of spring ligament, tarsal coalition, disruption of tibialis posterior tendon, tarsometatarsal arthritis, and hindfoot degenerative or inflammatory arthritis.

Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

It supports the head of the talus which if fails or is destroyed, leads to separation of the navicular and calcaneus, in turn allowing the talar head, the highest point of the arch, to descend and leading to a flat-foot deformity.

Other options:

The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilizes the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are most common when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture. Both the deltoid and spring ligaments are present on the medial side and their injuries are common in eversion sprains.

The anterior talofibular ligament is the “ankle sprain ligament” because it is the one that is most often damaged when the ankle is rolled.

The posterior talofibular ligament functions to stabilize the ankle joint and subtalar joint. Injuries are rare to this ligament unless there is an ankle dislocation or subluxation. The talofibular ligaments are present on the lateral side and their injuries are common in inversion sprains.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

questions.text:
The statements given below are the events related to intrauterine death. Arrange them in the sequence of occurrence from earliest to latest:
  1. Serous cavities filled with red turbid fluid
  2. Loss of alignment and overriding of bones of the cranial vault
  3. Reddening of the skin with peeling
  4. Large blebs containing serosanguinous fluid
questions.solution:
The sequence of events occurring in maceration from earliest to latest is given by option D i.e. 3-4-1-2. 

Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis occurring after the intrauterine death of the fetus. This process occurs when the dead fetus remains in utero for 3-4 days and is surrounded by the liquor amnii. If air enters the liquor amnii after the death of the fetus, putrefaction occurs instead of maceration.

Signs of intrauterine death:

  • Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
  • Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
  • Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours 
  • Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
  • Spalding's sign - radiographic finding seen as a loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of the cranial vault. This occurs due to shrinkage of the brain after death. It is seen within a few days of fetal death.
  • A sweetish and disagreeable odor
  • Sodden and coppery red/purplish skin (never greenish as with putrefaction) with blisters, and cuticle peeling. The skin detaches easily and leaves moist and greasy areas
  • Distended abdomen and thick, red, and soft umbilical cord
  • Abnormally mobile or flexible joints
  • Soft, edematous, and loss of morphology of the organs or viscera (lungs and uterus remain unaffected for long period)
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with uncontrolled bleeding from the nose, that failed to settle with conservative methods. When examined, the bleeding point was difficult to localize. A transnasal endoscopic procedure was performed for artery ligation. An adjunctive procedure was performed in order to further control the epistaxis, with the incision shown in the image below. Which among the following arteries are exposed and ligated following this incision?
questions.solution:
The incision shown in the given image is the Lynch incision (external ethmoid incision), which exposes the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries. The anterior ethmoidal artery is often ligated as an adjunctive procedure to Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL).

Spontaneous epistaxis in a hypertensive patient, >40 years of age which is difficult to localize is suggestive of posterior epistaxis.

  Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis
Site Little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity, or difficult to localize
Age Children, young adults >40 years of age
Cause Usually trauma Spontaneous, due to hypertension or IHD
Bleeding Mild, easily controlled with conservative measures (pressure, anterior nasal pack) Severe requires hospitalization and posterior nasal pack

 

Management of Epistaxis:

  1. Pinching of the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 min compresses the vessels of the Little’s area.
  2. Trotter’s method: The patient sits, leaning forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathes quietly from the mouth. Cold compresses should be applied to the nose to cause reflex vasoconstriction.
  3. Cauterisation of the bleeding point- with silver nitrate or electrocautery. This is done under topical anesthesia.
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing - Patients should be hospitalized.
  6. Endoscopic cauterization of the bleeding point. 
  7. Elevation of the mucoperichondrial flap and submucosal resection operation- for persistent and recurrent bleeds from the septum.
  8. Ligations of vessels:
    • External carotid artery.
    • Maxillary artery- Approached via Caldwell Luc operation.
    • Ethmoidal arteries- Approached via Lynch incision.
  9. Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL)- Under topical anesthesia with sedation or under general anesthesia, the sphenopalatine artery (SPA) is localized and closed with a vascular clip as it exits the foramen. The anterior ethmoidal artery is often ligated by Lynch incision as an adjunctive procedure. It is effective in controlling posterior bleeds.
  10. Embolization of the maxillary arteries by an interventional radiologist, via femoral artery catheterization. Ethmoidal arteries cannot be embolized.

questions.text: Which of the following schedule includes psychotropic drugs warranting a special license for manufacturing and sales?
questions.solution:
Schedule X includes psychotropic drugs requiring a special license for manufacturing and sales.

Schedule X drugs have high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only. The chemist must maintain a prescription in duplicate, separate license requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records.

The Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945 are the set of rules under The Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 which contains provisions for the classification of drugs under given schedules and there are guidelines for the storage, sale, display, and prescription of each schedule.

Any stereoisomeric form of the substance, any salt of the substance, or the preparations containing the substances specified in this schedule is covered by schedule X.

These drugs include

  • Amobarbital
  • Glutethimide
  • Pentobarbital
  • Ketamine hydrochloride
  • Amphetamine
  • Meprobamate
  • Phencyclidine
  • Barbital
  • Methamphetamine
  • Phenmetrazine
  • Cyclobarbital
  • Dexamphetamine
  • Methylphenidate
  • Secobarbital
  • Ethclorvynol
  • Methylphenobarbital.

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

Schedule Details

Schedule D List of drugs exempted from the provision of import of drugs.

F II - Specification of standards for Surgical dressing

FF- Specification of standard Ophthalmic preparation

Schedule M Regulations regarding good manufacturing practices

Schedule X Drugs having abuse and dependence liability.
Schedule Y Requirement and guidelines for import/ manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: Which of the following proto-oncogenes is not a GTP-binding protein?
questions.solution:
ABL is not a GTP-binding protein. It is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase protein.

The ABL gene undergoes translocation from chromosome 9 to chromosome 22 in chronic myelogenous leukemia and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Because of this translocation, it fuses with the BCR gene. The resultant fusion gene codes for BCR-ABL protein, a chimeric protein with tyrosine kinase activity.

GNAQ, HRAS, and KRAS are GTP-binding proteins that undergo point mutation to cause tumors:

  • GNAQ is associated with uveal melanomas.
  • HRAS is associated with bladder and kidney tumors.
  • KRAS is associated with colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors.
